The IMD warns of a heatwave in coastal Andhra Pradesh, while internationally, former US President Donald Trump faces trial over a hush money case. Tensions rise between Iran and Israel following Iran's missile attack. Kejriwal remains in custody, and Trump's trial marks a historic first for a former US president.

item.title: How US, UK, France and Jordan came to Israel’s rescue as Iran attacked
item.description: In a coordinated defense against an Iranian attack, Israel successfully intercepted 99% of over 300 drones and missiles with the aid of its allies. The U.S. played a pivotal role, deploying forces and missile defense systems to the region, intercepting numerous threats. The UK's Royal Air Force also contributed by downing Iranian drones, while France assisted in airspace patrol. Even Jordan, despite past criticisms of Israel, engaged in the defense, shooting down drones that breached its airspace. This international effort underscored the strategic alliances and defense capabilities mobilized to protect Israel from the significant assault.

item.title: What is the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, the group believed to be behind Iran’s attack on Israel?
item.description: In retaliation for an Israeli airstrike on its consulate in Damascus, Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) launched a significant attack from Iranian soil against Israel, claiming to have achieved all its objectives. The IRGC, established after the 1979 Islamic Revolution, is a parallel military force to Iran's traditional armed forces, reporting directly to the Supreme Leader. With 190,000 personnel and influence over Iran's politics and economy, the IRGC also operates the Quds Force, impacting militias across the Middle East. The U.S. has designated the IRGC as a terrorist organization, citing its involvement in various regional conflicts and support for other designated terrorist groups. The IRGC's role extends to Iran's politics, with many former officers holding governmental positions, and it controls significant economic sectors within the country.

item.title: Arrow defence system: Israel’s weapon against Iran’s rain of drones and missiles
item.description: In a significant escalation, Iran directly targeted Israel with drones and missiles from its territory for the first time on April 13. The attack aimed at Tel Aviv, Jerusalem, and Dimona, where Israel's nuclear facility is located. Israel's military confirmed the attack, stating that their Arrow aerial defense system successfully intercepted 99% of the incoming threats. Iran's Revolutionary Guards claimed the attack was retaliation for a strike in Damascus that killed seven of their members. The Arrow system, developed with the US, is part of Israel's multi-layered defense, designed to neutralize long-range missiles outside the atmosphere. It complements other systems like Iron Dome, David's Sling, and Patriot, providing Israel with a comprehensive aerial defense capability. The Arrow system has been operational since the 1990s, with continuous advancements such as the Arrow 3, enhancing Israel's defense against ballistic missiles and weapons of mass destruction.

item.title: How Israel shielded itself from more than 300 Iranian drones, missiles
item.description: Tensions in West Asia intensified as Iran launched a direct military assault on Israel, firing hundreds of drones and missiles. This aggressive move was in retaliation for an Israeli attack on an Iranian consulate in Damascus, which resulted in the deaths of Iranian officials. The majority of the Iranian projectiles were intercepted by Israel's defense systems, with assistance from the US, UK, and France. Despite the extensive aerial attack, only minor structural damage was reported at the Nevatim Airbase in southern Israel, and there were no casualties from the strikes. The UN Security Council convened an emergency meeting in response to the attacks, which have escalated the ongoing covert war between the two nations. World leaders have condemned Iran's actions, emphasizing solidarity with Israel and calling for an immediate cessation of hostilities.

item.title: This Week in Explainers: Why Iran launched an attack against Israel
item.description: This week's global news includes Iran's attack on Israel with over 200 missiles and drones, escalating tensions in West Asia. The assault was a response to an airstrike on Iran's consulate in Syria. In Asia, South Korea's elections dealt a significant blow to President Yoon Suk Yeol, while Vietnam sentenced a businesswoman to death for a major financial fraud. Saudi Arabia is downsizing its ambitious megacity project, The Line, and British PM Rishi Sunak's footwear choice has unexpectedly impacted Adidas' Samba shoes' reputation. Additionally, Sierra Leone faces a national emergency due to widespread drug use, leading to grave robberies linked to kush consumption.

item.title: Think yourself: Why we should not let AI make decisions for us
item.description: As AI becomes more integrated into daily life, concerns about its influence on decision-making grow. The fear of AI going rogue is less pressing than the social issues it may exacerbate, such as privacy invasion, bias, and lack of transparency. A psychologist's research suggests that AI's most significant threat is its potential to undermine human decision-making skills. Thoughtful decision-making involves understanding the problem, considering multiple options, and delaying closure to weigh all information. AI, however, often provides context-free answers, depriving individuals of the chance to practice making informed choices. This reliance on AI could perpetuate biases and hinder critical reasoning. item.title: Can pregnancy cause women to age faster?
item.description:
The article discusses a study published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences which found that pregnancy can accelerate biological ageing in women. The study, which used data from the Cebu Longitudinal Health and Nutrition Survey, analyzed blood samples from 1,735 individuals and considered factors like socioeconomic status and pollution. It utilized "epigenetic clocks" to measure biological age and found that women who had given birth showed a three percent annual increase in biological age compared to those who hadn't, with the ageing process accelerating further with each additional pregnancy.
Associate research scientist Calen Ryan suggests that the physical demands of pregnancy might contribute to this accelerated ageing, but also notes that there is evidence of recovery post-pregnancy. The extent of this recovery and its variation among individuals remains unclear. A Yale School of Medicine study indicates that the ageing process may reverse somewhat after giving birth. Lifestyle adjustments post-pregnancy, such as proper nutrition, physical activity, and stress reduction, are recommended to help mitigate these effects. The article emphasizes the need for more research to fully understand the long-term effects of pregnancy on biological ageing. Please note that this summary is based on the information provided and should not replace professional medical advice.

item.title: Save every drop: Why Colombia’s capital Bogota is rationing water
item.description:
Bogotá, Colombia's capital, is experiencing a severe water shortage due to critically low reservoir levels, exacerbated by an acute drought and the El Niño climate phenomenon. In response, the city has implemented water rationing measures, dividing the city into nine zones with water services turned off for 24 hours on a rotational basis every 10 days. Hospitals and schools are exempt, and the situation is reviewed bi-weekly.
Mayor Carlos Fernando Galán has called for conservation, stating that reduced consumption can hasten the lifting of restrictions. Residents have begun reducing water usage, with some unable to perform tasks like washing cars. The emergency measures aim to lower water consumption from 17 cubic meters per second to 15, saving 2,000 liters per second.
The crisis is attributed to the city's reliance on surface water from reservoirs like Chuza and San Rafael, which are at historic lows. Bogotá's unique dependence on rain for its water supply makes it vulnerable to drought. President Gustavo Petro has called for substantial changes to protect water resources and prepare for future crises, criticizing unchecked urbanization and exploitation of natural aquifers.

item.title: In a first, US limits ‘forever chemicals’ in tap water: What health risks do PFAS pose?
item.description:
The article discusses the US Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) recent action to set the first-ever national drinking water standards for per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS), also known as 'forever chemicals'. Here's a summary:
**Background on PFAS:** - PFAS are a large group of human-made chemicals used in consumer products and industry for their resistance to water, grease, and stains. - They are found in many everyday items, including nonstick cookware, waterproof apparel, cosmetics, and food packaging. - Despite their usefulness, PFAS are persistent in the environment and have been detected in water, soil, living organisms, and even remote areas like Arctic glaciers.
**Health Risks:** - PFAS can remain in the human body for a long time and accumulate, posing various health risks. - Research links PFAS exposure to thyroid disease, elevated cholesterol, liver damage, kidney and testicular cancer, and developmental issues in babies. - There is also evidence suggesting PFAS may contribute to other disorders, such as inflammatory bowel disease, reduced fertility, and breast cancer.
**Regulation Efforts:** - The EPA's new standards limit five individual PFAS chemicals and their mixtures in drinking water. - The agency also proposed listing nine PFAS as hazardous substances, which has raised concerns about cleanup costs. - In the absence of federal regulation, states have implemented their own laws to protect against PFAS exposure, creating a patchwork of regulations.
**Reducing PFAS Exposure:** - Most exposure to PFAS comes from diet, but drinking water and airborne exposures can also be significant. - To reduce exposure, individuals should educate themselves about potential sources and check product labels for PFAS content. - The article suggests consulting the Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, EPA, and US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for more information on PFAS.
The article emphasizes the importance of being informed about PFAS and taking steps to minimize exposure, while highlighting the regulatory actions taken to address the associated risks. It is republished from The Conversation under a Creative Commons license.

item.title: What are UK’s new strict visa rules? Should Indians worry?
item.description:
The UK has implemented new visa rules to curb migration, following a record influx of 745,000 people in 2022. The changes, described by Prime Minister Rishi Sunak as necessary due to the high numbers, include:
**New Work Visa Rules:** - The minimum salary for work visas has increased by nearly 50% from £26,200 to £38,700. - Exceptions exist for jobs in health, social care, and teaching, which have a lower salary threshold. - The "shortage occupation list" includes roles like health and care workers, pharmacists, graphic designers, construction workers, and vets with a lower salary requirement. - Overseas care workers cannot bring family dependents. - Skilled worker visas require application through the points-based system (PBS), effective from April 4.
**Points-Based System (PBS):** - Applicants need 70 points to qualify, with 50 points awarded for a job offer above a minimum skill level and English proficiency. - Additional 20 points can be earned for higher salary, shortage field employment, or relevant PhD.
**Family Visa Norms:** - A minimum salary of £29,000 is required to sponsor a loved one, set to increase to £34,500 and £38,700 in the coming years. - New applicants must meet the threshold, but renewals are exempt. - Critics argue the rules separate families and damage the UK's reputation as a family-friendly country. - Home Secretary James Cleverly defends the rules as protection for British workers and taxpayers.
**Impact on Indians:** - Indians, a major group seeking UK work visas, will be affected, with a 63% increase in work visa grants from 2021-22 to 2022-23. - Indian nationals lead in the 'Worker' category, particularly in 'Skilled Worker' and 'Health and Care' visas. - The raised salary threshold means Indians earning below cannot work in the UK. - Since January 2024, foreign postgraduate students can't bring dependents unless on a research program. - Indian study visa grants have surged, with a 63% increase from the previous year, now seven times higher than in 2019.
These measures reflect the UK's effort to manage immigration numbers while facing criticism for potentially separating families and impacting certain worker groups.

item.title: There’s a whooping cough outbreak worldwide: How deadly is it?

The infection, caused by the bacterium Bordetella pertussis, is particularly dangerous for infants and children. Despite the availability of vaccines since the 1950s, the disease remains a significant cause of death among children worldwide.
The symptoms, initially resembling a common cold, can escalate to severe coughing fits with a distinctive "whoop" sound. Vaccination has been effective in reducing the severity and duration of the disease, yet many countries only mandate it for children, leaving adults vulnerable after the vaccine's protection wanes.
The recent spike in cases has been attributed to the disruption of routine vaccination during the COVID-19 pandemic, leading to decreased immunity and increased susceptibility. The resurgence follows a lull in cases due to pandemic-related measures like border closures and social distancing.
To combat the rise, health authorities emphasize the importance of vaccination for all age groups. Some countries are experiencing vaccine shortages, highlighting the need for sustained immunization efforts to prevent future outbreaks. The situation underscores the delicate balance between disease control and maintaining herd immunity through vaccination.

item.title: Why Saudi Arabia is scaling back plans for its mega desert project Neom
item.description:
Saudi Arabia's ambitious NEOM project, specifically the 170-km-long linear city known as 'The Line', is being scaled back significantly. Initially intended to accommodate 1.5 million residents by 2030, it will now house no more than 300,000. The Line was envisioned as a car-less city powered by renewable energy, with all daily needs within a five-minute walk and a high-speed rail system for longer distances. However, due to economic constraints, including unapproved budgets and the need for additional funding from the state, the project's scope has been reduced. Only 2.4 km of the original 170 km is expected to be completed by 2030. This scale-back has led to job losses as contractors dismiss workers.
The reduction in scale is attributed to several factors, including the economic viability and changing visions for the project. Oil revenues, which are crucial for funding, have not met the necessary levels to support the government's budget. Additionally, the project's feasibility has been questioned due to its reliance on technologies that do not yet exist.
Environmentalists and human rights activists have expressed relief over the project's downsizing. The Line's design posed a threat to migratory birds, and there were concerns about its environmental impact. Human rights issues also arose from the displacement of the Howeitat tribe for the project's development, leading to arrests and detentions among the tribe members. The scale-back may alleviate some of these environmental and social concerns.

item.title: Explained: Why a new European pact on migration and asylum is controversial
item.description:
The European Union (EU) has approved a significant reform of its migration and asylum rules, known as the EU Migration and Asylum Pact. This pact, which has been in development since 2015, aims to address the division over managing unauthorized entries by hardening border procedures and mandating all 27 EU nations to share responsibility for migrants. The pact includes controversial measures such as taking biometric data from children, detaining individuals during screening, and fast-track deportations. It also introduces a new border processing system to swiftly determine migrants' status upon arrival, with a goal to process asylum requests within 12 weeks.
The legislation has caused division within the EU, with the European Parliament's main political groups overcoming opposition from far-right and far-left parties to pass the new pact. The far-right parties believe the reforms are not strict enough, while the far-left argues they are too stringent and abandon Europe's values of compassion and human dignity. Human rights activists and organizations have criticized the pact for potentially leading to greater human suffering.
The reform has been described as historic by some EU leaders, while others, like Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban, have expressed strong dissent. The pact's approval comes amid rising numbers of migrants entering Europe, with 380,000 illegal border crossings reported last year, the highest number since 2016. The EU issued almost 3.7 million new residence permits in 2022, and there were 875,000 new asylum applications, not including those from Ukrainian applicants. The member states must now endorse the reform package before it can take effect.

item.title: Fact-check: The truth behind the ‘challenge vote’ in 2024 Lok Sabha elections
item.description:
Here's a summary of the article:
As India prepares for the 2024 Lok Sabha elections, a viral message has been circulating online about "challenge votes" and "tendered votes." The message claims that if a person's name is not on the voter list, they can still vote by showing their Aadhaar card or voter ID and asking for a "challenge vote" under Section 49P. Additionally, it suggests that if someone has already voted in their name, they can request a "tendered vote." It also states that if more than 14% of votes at a polling booth are tendered, a repoll will be conducted.
However, these claims are largely false: - **First Claim (False):** The Election Commission of India (ECI) has clarified that if a person's name is not on the voter list, they cannot vote. The term "challenge vote" is incorrect; the correct term is "challenged vote," which involves a polling agent challenging a voter's identity, not related to Aadhaar or voter ID cards. - **Second Claim (True):** Section 49P does deal with "tendered votes," which are allowed if someone has already voted under a person's name. These votes are marked differently and are not counted in the main tally unless they are likely to affect the election outcome. - **Third Claim (False):** There is no rule for repolling if tendered votes exceed 14%. Tendered votes are considered only if they could change the election result, and that too only on the direction of a High Court.
In conclusion, the message about "challenge votes" and repolling due to tendered votes is false, while the provision for "tendered votes" is accurate but with specific conditions for their consideration.

The crisis affects all social strata, from the poor to the wealthy elite, and has overwhelmed the country's only psychiatric hospital. The national emergency aims to prioritize resources and interventions to combat the epidemic.

item.title: India among nations with highest hepatitis B and C cases: What are these infections, how to prevent them?
item.description:
Here's a summary of the article:
**India's Hepatitis B and C Burden:** - India has the second-highest number of hepatitis B and C cases globally, following China. - In 2022, India had 3.5 crore cases, representing 11.6% of the global infection burden. - Hepatitis B and C are leading causes of liver inflammation and are significant infectious killers, with 1.3 million deaths annually.
**WHO Report Findings:** - The WHO's Global Hepatitis Report 2024 indicates India had 2.93 crore people with hepatitis B and 55 lakh with hepatitis C in 2022. - New cases and deaths: 50,000 new hepatitis B cases, 1.4 lakh new hepatitis C cases, and deaths numbering 98,305 (B) and 26,206 (C). - Diagnosis coverage is low, with only 2.4% of infected individuals receiving it. - Globally, deaths from viral hepatitis increased from 1.1 million in 2019 to 1.3 million in 2022.
**Disease Overview:** - Hepatitis B and C account for 96% of hepatitis mortality. - Hepatitis B can lead to acute infection, cirrhosis, and liver cancer. - Hepatitis C often goes unnoticed and can cause various symptoms after 2-12 weeks of exposure.
**Transmission and Differences:** - Both diseases spread through unsafe injection practices, contaminated blood products, and from mother to child. - Hepatitis B can also spread through bodily fluids, while C is primarily transmitted through blood-to-blood contact.
**India's Response:** - The hepatitis B vaccine is part of the Universal Immunisation Programme. - Despite high vaccine coverage, birth-dose coverage remains low. - Experts call for complete vaccination for newborns and adults born before the vaccine's national program inclusion.
**Treatment and Control:** - Hepatitis B treatment follows guidelines, but many diagnosed are ineligible for treatment. - Hepatitis C has a short-term treatment course lasting 12 to 24 weeks, with a high cure rate.
The article emphasizes the need for better diagnosis, treatment access, and vaccination coverage to tackle the hepatitis burden in India. It also highlights the differences in transmission and effects of hepatitis B and C, underscoring the global challenge posed by these infections.

item.title: Peter Higgs passes away: The ‘shy man’ behind the God Particle
item.description:
Peter Higgs, the British physicist renowned for his work on the Higgs boson particle, has passed away at the age of 94. The Nobel laureate, who was averse to the term 'God Particle', made significant contributions to the field of theoretical physics, particularly with his prediction of the Higgs boson in 1964. This particle is a fundamental aspect of the Standard Model of particle physics, explaining how other particles acquire mass.
Higgs was born in Newcastle-upon-Tyne and showed early promise in science, though initially in chemistry. He pursued physics at King's College London and later joined the University of Edinburgh, where he remained until retirement. His groundbreaking paper in 1964 laid the foundation for the discovery of the Higgs boson, which was confirmed in 2012 by experiments at CERN's Large Hadron Collider.
In 2013, Higgs was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics alongside Francois Englert. Despite the accolades, Higgs maintained a low profile, preferring to avoid the limelight. Tributes from the scientific community highlight his humility, politeness, and encouragement of young scientists.
Higgs's legacy extends beyond his Nobel-winning theory; his work has implications for our understanding of the universe, including the potential connection between the Higgs boson and dark matter. His passing is mourned by many, who remember him as a visionary and a gentleman of science.

item.title: How Joe Biden's plan to cancel student loans could benefit more than 30 million Americans
item.description:
President Joe Biden has introduced a new student loan cancellation proposal following the rejection of his first plan by the US Supreme Court. Here's a summary of the key differences and details:
**Differences from the First Plan:** - The **first plan** proposed cancelling $10,000 of debt for individuals earning up to $125,000 annually, with an additional $10,000 for Pell Grant recipients, benefiting over 40 million people. - The **new plan** is more targeted, focusing on those facing significant challenges due to student debt, and is expected to help around 30 million borrowers.
**Legal Justification:** - The first plan was rejected because the Supreme Court deemed Biden overstepped his authority. - The new plan uses the **Higher Education Act** as its legal basis, allowing the Education Secretary to waive student loan debt under certain conditions.
**Eligibility:** - The new proposal targets five categories of borrowers, particularly those with growing debt due to unpaid interest, eligible federal forgiveness programs, long-term repayment, attendance at low-value programs, or facing hardship preventing repayment. - Up to $20,000 in interest cancellation is available for those owing more than originally borrowed, without an income cap for individuals earning less than $120,000 or couples earning less than $240,000.
**Implementation:** - Most cancellations will be automatic, except for borrowers claiming hardship, who must apply individually. - The plan could start as early as this fall, with the possibility of early implementation authorized by the Higher Education Act.
**Potential Challenges:** - The plan may face legal challenges, with opponents arguing that widespread loan cancellation should come from Congress. - If overturned after implementation, it's uncertain how cancelled debts would be handled.
This new approach aims to provide relief more strategically, focusing on those in dire need while navigating legal and political hurdles. The administration is optimistic but prepared for potential challenges ahead.

item.title: Why getting work visas to New Zealand just got tougher
item.description:

- **English language requirements** for low-skilled jobs. - A **minimum skills and work experience threshold** for most employer work visas. - Reduction of the **maximum continuous stay** for low-skilled roles to **three years** from five.
Employers must now ensure that no suitable New Zealand candidate is available before hiring a migrant and justify why local applicants were not selected. Certain sectors, like care and transportation, are exempt from these new requirements.
The aim is to protect migrants from exploitation and prioritize New Zealanders for jobs without skill shortages. The government also plans to create a smarter immigration system that manages net migration, attracts top talent, and is sustainable.

item.title: How India's Aditya L-1 will track the Sun during the total solar eclipse

**Scientific Significance:** - Solar eclipses offer insights into the Sun's structure and the discovery of new elements. - They allow the study of the Sun's corona and help understand solar winds' impact on Earth. - Eclipses also provide a unique opportunity to study Earth's atmosphere under altered solar radiation conditions.

item.title: Is kanyandan relevant today? Why Allahabad HC said ritual is not essential in Hindu marriage

They argue for the empowerment of women and the elimination of practices that treat women as property.
The court's decision came during the case of Ashutosh Yadav, who argued that his marriage was invalid because the kanyadan ceremony was not performed. The court dismissed this claim, emphasizing that saptpadi is the essential ceremony for a Hindu marriage, not kanyadan.
The article also touches on the historical significance of kanyadan and how some believe it is a misunderstood tradition that symbolizes parental blessings rather than the transfer of property. The discussion reflects a broader societal shift towards reevaluating and potentially reforming traditional practices to align with contemporary values of equality and women's agency. **Please note that this summary is based on the information provided in the article and may not reflect the most current legal standings or societal views.**

item.title: Ecuador police break into Mexican embassy: How a diplomatic crisis has unfolded
item.description:

2. **Violation of International Law**: The intrusion into the embassy is seen as a breach of the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations, which protects diplomatic premises from being entered forcibly. This has raised concerns about the respect for international laws that safeguard diplomatic missions.
3. **Political Ramifications**: Glas, convicted of corruption, had sought asylum in the embassy, and his arrest has provoked outrage and debate over the legality and propriety of providing refuge to someone facing legal charges.

item.title: Explained: How different religions deal with a solar eclipse
item.description:
The article discusses the significance of solar eclipses in various religious traditions. **Solar eclipses**, which occur when the Moon obscures the Sun for a brief period, have historically been interpreted as divine messages, causing feelings of awe or fear.
In **Buddhism**, particularly within the Tibetan tradition, eclipses are seen as times when the effects of actions are magnified, making them auspicious for spiritual practices like chanting mantras.
**Christianity** has mixed views, with some interpreting eclipses as signs of the end times, while others see them as metaphors for spiritual transitions, especially in relation to the crucifixion of Jesus.
**Hindu legends** attribute eclipses to the celestial beings Rahu and Ketu, with many Hindus considering eclipses as bad omens and engaging in fasting, ritual baths, and prayers during these times.
In **Islam**, eclipses are occasions for prayer and reflection, not linked to any earthly events. The Prophet Muhammad emphasized that eclipses are natural signs from Allah and should not be associated with superstitions.
**Judaism** does not have specific blessings for eclipses, viewing them instead as bad omens. However, modern interpretations suggest they should prompt introspection and prayer.
Overall, the article illustrates that while solar eclipses are natural phenomena, they hold deep spiritual meaning across different faiths, often seen as times for increased devotion and reflection. The article includes insights from religious scholars and references to religious texts to support these views.

item.title: Rest in Space: What happens to human ashes in space? Do they return to Earth?
item.description:

This trend has been highlighted by the story of Elizabeth Garcia, whose ashes were sent 100,000 feet above Earth by a UK company specializing in space memorials. The practice is legal and has attracted a diverse clientele, including high-profile individuals like Star Trek creator Gene Roddenberry.
The ashes released during these space burials do not contribute to space junk, as they are dispersed well below satellite orbits and eventually return to Earth, joining the natural cycle as rain or snow. Companies like Aura Flights and Ascension Flights facilitate these burials, with costs ranging from a few thousand to over ten thousand dollars, making it a more accessible option for many.
While some experts suggest that legislative frameworks may need to adapt to the growing number of companies offering this service, the consensus is that space burials do not pose a threat to satellites or contribute to space debris. However, there is a slight possibility that some particles could escape into orbit and add to the millions of tiny bits of space junk.
In summary, space burials offer a unique way for individuals to fulfill their dreams of space travel, even in death, and allow for a final tribute that aligns with their values and interests. The process is environmentally friendly, as the ashes ultimately return to Earth, and does not contribute to the problem of space junk.

item.title: Earthquake rattles New York City: Why temblors are uncommon in the area
item.description:
On April 5, 2024, a rare 4.8 magnitude earthquake struck the New York City area, with the epicenter located near Lebanon, New Jersey. The tremor was felt across the northeastern US, from Pennsylvania to Massachusetts, around 10:23 am ET. Despite the shaking of buildings and skyscrapers, no significant damage or injuries were reported.
The occurrence of earthquakes in the New York City region is uncommon. The USGS notes that earthquakes typically occur along tectonic plate fault lines, but can happen anywhere, anytime. The Ramapo Fault in New Jersey and at least five smaller fault lines under Manhattan are noted contributors to seismic activity in the area.
Historically, New York City has experienced 19 significant earthquakes since 1737, with the recent one being among the stronger ones, occurring infrequently but periodically. The East Coast is less prone to earthquakes compared to the West Coast due to its location away from tectonic plate boundaries. However, ancient stresses in the Earth's crust can still cause occasional tremors. The bedrock under the East Coast is older and harder, which allows seismic energy to travel further, making earthquakes felt over a broader area.
This summary captures the key points of the article, providing an overview of the seismic event and its context within the geological history of New York City.

**Understanding Prostate Cancer:** - Prostate cancer originates in the prostate gland, which produces seminal fluid. - It varies in aggressiveness, with some forms requiring additional treatments like radiation, surgery, hormone therapy, or chemotherapy.
**Symptoms:** - Symptoms include incomplete bladder emptying, frequent urination, urgency, and blood in urine or semen. - Not all symptoms indicate cancer; they can also be due to benign prostate enlargement.
**Prevalence in India:** - Prostate cancer is the second most common cancer globally. - In India, 33,000 to 42,000 new cases are reported annually, accounting for 3% of all cancers. - The incidence has increased significantly over the past 25 years, particularly in urban areas.
**Treatment:** - Treatment depends on the cancer's progression and overall health condition. - It may involve screenings, scans, biopsies, therapies, or surgery.
The study highlights the need for proactive planning and action to manage the anticipated surge in prostate cancer cases. The findings will be presented at the European Association of Urology's annual congress in Paris.

item.title: How Taiwan’s tallest building, Taipei 101, stood tall amid the 7.4-strong earthquake
item.description: A 7.4-magnitude earthquake struck Taiwan, resulting in 12 fatalities and over 1,000 injuries. Despite the destruction of 770 buildings, Taipei 101, a skyscraper once considered the world's tallest, withstood the quake with minimal damage. This was possible due to its massive tuned mass damper, known as "Damper Baby," a 660-tonne steel sphere suspended between the 87th and 92nd floors. The damper sways to counteract building movement during seismic activity or high winds, reducing motion by up to 40%. The system is entirely passive, relying on gravity and the building's movement, and is visible to visitors on the observation deck. The earthquake, the strongest to hit Taiwan in 25 years, caused significant infrastructure damage and left hundreds stranded. The epicenter was near Hualien County, an area prone to seismic activity. Taiwan's earthquake monitoring agency reported a magnitude of 7.2, while the US Geological Survey recorded it at 7.4. The Taipei 101's resilience highlights the importance of advanced engineering in safeguarding structures against natural disasters.

item.title: How much indelible ink will it take to hold Lok Sabha polls? Here are the numbers
item.description:
Mysore Paints and Varnish Ltd (MPVL) has completed the delivery of over 26.55 lakh vials of indelible ink, valued at around Rs 55 crore, for the 2024 Lok Sabha elections. The largest portion of this supply is designated for Uttar Pradesh. This ink, which marks voters' left forefingers to indicate they've voted and prevent fraud, is a crucial element in maintaining the integrity of the electoral process.
The ink is produced exclusively by MPVL, following a formula developed by the Council of Industrial Research-National Physical Laboratory in Delhi. MPVL has been the sole manufacturer of this ink for the Election Commission since 1962.
The upcoming seven-phase Lok Sabha elections are set to begin on 19 April, with vote counting scheduled for 4 June. Assembly elections in Andhra Pradesh, Odisha, Sikkim, and Arunachal Pradesh will occur simultaneously.
Compared to the previous parliamentary elections, there's a 2.2% increase in the supply of indelible ink. In 2019, MPVL supplied over 25.98 lakh vials worth approximately Rs 36 crore, with Uttar Pradesh receiving the highest order of 3.64 lakh vials and Lakshadweep the lowest at 125 vials.
India's voter base is nearly 97 crore, with Uttar Pradesh having the most voters at over 15.30 crore and Lakshadweep the fewest at 57,500. This year, Uttar Pradesh received 3.58 lakh vials, while Lakshadweep got 110 vials.
Other states' supplies include Maharashtra (2.68 lakh vials), West Bengal (2 lakh), Bihar (1.93 lakh), Tamil Nadu (1.75 lakh), and so on, with smaller regions like Goa receiving 5,000 vials. Each 10 ml vial can mark approximately 700 voters, and a typical polling station serves about 1,500 voters.
The indelible ink is also exported to over 25 countries, with application methods varying by country—finger dipping in Cambodia and the Maldives, brush application in Burkina Faso, and nozzle use in Turkey.
This summary captures the key points of the article, highlighting the scale of MPVL's operations and the significance of indelible ink in safeguarding democratic elections both in India and abroad.

item.title: Lok Sabha Elections 2024: Do voters no longer trust independent candidates?
item.description: The upcoming 18th general election in India prompts discussions about the state of democracy, particularly regarding independent candidates. Data from the Election Commission of India reveals that since 1991, over 99% of independent candidates have lost their deposits, indicating a decline in voter trust in them. While the number of independent candidates remains high, their success rate has decreased significantly over the years. Factors contributing to this trend include the rise of regional parties, voters' increasing awareness and access to information, and the perception that independent candidates lack the ability to fulfill promises or bring about significant change. In the 2019 Lok Sabha elections, out of over 8,000 independent candidates, only four won seats, further highlighting their diminishing relevance in Indian politics.

item.title: FirstUp: RBI policy to be announced, Congress to release poll manifesto... Top news today
item.description:
The article outlines the events of the day, highlighting key occurrences:
1. RBI's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) will announce its decision on key interest rates. Expectations suggest a status quo due to caution over inflation.
2. Congress is set to release its manifesto for the upcoming Lok Sabha election, focusing on welfare initiatives known as 'Paanch Nyay.'
3. A Delhi court summons Congress MP Karti Chidambaram and others in a money laundering case related to an alleged Chinese visa scam.
4. The Enforcement Directorate (ED) summons the brother of Jharkhand Congress MLA Amba Prasad for questioning in a money laundering case.
5. Vice President Jagdeep Dhankhar is scheduled to visit Dehradun and Mussoorie for various engagements, including a ceremony at the Lal Bahadur Shastri National Academy of Administration.
6. In IPL 2024, Sunrisers Hyderabad (SRH) will face Chennai Super Kings (CSK) at the Rajiv Gandhi International Cricket Stadium in Hyderabad.
The article also mentions notable historical events and birthdays for the day.

item.title: Israel-Hamas war marks six months: What are the issues now?
item.description: The Israel-Hamas war, ongoing for six months, has resulted in significant casualties, particularly among Palestinians, with approximately 33,000 confirmed killed, including 40% children. Gaza faces a humanitarian crisis, with dire conditions such as displacement, hunger, and limited medical care. Mediators seek a ceasefire to deliver aid and secure the release of hostages held by Hamas. Gaza is under blockade, limiting aid access, and is on the brink of famine. Israel's impending assault on Rafah raises concerns of further humanitarian catastrophe. Ceasefire talks continue, but differences persist. The war has escalated tensions in the region, including clashes with Hezbollah, violence in the West Bank, and airstrikes in Syria and Iraq. Israel's relationship with the US has strained, with criticism over civilian casualties and aid access.

item.title: What is ‘Quit-Tok’, the viral job quitting trend making companies squirm?
item.description: The rise of "Quit-Tok" on TikTok has caught the attention of many, as employees are now documenting their resignations and sharing them in real-time on social media. This trend, which follows the "loud quitting" phenomenon, involves workers filming the moment they tender their resignation or capture their bosses firing them, often with the hashtag #quittok. The motivation behind this trend varies, with some seeing it as a way to expose bad workplace behavior or a poor office environment, while others view it as a means of gaining social media followers. However, while some believe that Quit-Tok holds companies more accountable for their treatment of employees, others caution against leaving jobs in a loud and public manner, as it could harm future career prospects and re-employment opportunities within the same company.

item.title: Ramesh Kunhikannan: The man who joined Forbes list of billionaires, courtesy Chandrayaan-3
item.description: Ramesh Kunhikannan, the CEO and founder of Kaynes Technology in India, has recently made it onto the Forbes Billionaires list with a net worth of $1.2 billion. His company's contribution to India's historic Chandrayaan-3 mission played a significant role in his newfound billionaire status. Kaynes Technology provided the electrical systems for the Chandrayaan-3 lander and rover, boosting Kunhikannan's company shares and his personal net worth. The mission, launched by ISRO, aimed to explore the lunar surface and contributed to India's growing presence in space exploration. Alongside Kunhikannan, other Indian billionaires, including Mukesh Ambani and Gautam Adani, have also made it onto the Forbes list, reflecting India's increasing economic prowess.

item.title: Why IITs are struggling to get students placed this season
item.description: IITs, India's prestigious institutions, are facing challenges in securing placements for their students this year. Reports indicate that around 30-35% of students across various IIT campuses are still awaiting job offers. Reasons for this include a global economic slowdown, making it difficult to attract international companies for placements. Negotiations over salary packages have been challenging, and many companies are cautious about hiring amid economic uncertainties. While domestic companies are still recruiting, international firms are hesitant. However, there's optimism that placements will improve, with IITs now more open to Indian startups and planning to invite new companies for the second phase of placements. Overall, experts estimate a 20-30% decline in placements compared to the previous year due to the economic slowdown.

item.title: Explained: How bandages can increase the risk of developing cancer
item.description: A recent study by Mamavation and Environmental Health News found that bandages from brands like Curad and Band-Aid contain concerning levels of PFAS, or forever chemicals. These substances, which resist grease and water, have been linked to health issues like cancer, obesity, and reproductive problems. Dr. Linda Birnbaum, a toxicologist, warns of the dangers of PFAS exposure, especially when in contact with open wounds. PFAS, widely used since the 1940s, are found in various consumer products and have been detected in human blood and tap water. The chemicals pose risks to wildlife and persist in the environment, making them a widespread concern.

item.title: Did YouTube green-lit ads with disinformation on Indian elections?
item.description: Rights groups Global Witness and Access Now have accused YouTube of approving over 40 ads containing false information about elections in India, with the aim of voter suppression. These ads, submitted in Hindi, Telugu, and English, violated YouTube's advertising and election misinformation policies. Despite this, all the ads were approved within 24 hours. The false information included claims such as not needing ID to vote, voting by text message, and the voting age being raised to 21, which could potentially incite violence or disrupt the electoral process. Both the rights groups and YouTube have reacted to the situation, with Access Now criticizing YouTube for failing to implement its own policies and questioning its role in ensuring free and fair elections. However, Google, YouTube's parent company, defended its actions, stating that none of the ads ran on its platform and that it applies its policies globally and consistently. The incident highlights the challenge of combating election disinformation, particularly in developing countries like India where social media platforms play a significant role in political discourse. With India being YouTube's largest market, the spread of misinformation on the platform poses a serious risk to electoral integrity.

item.title: Is Rishi Sunak staring at a crushing electoral loss in the UK?
item.description: The latest survey suggests that Rishi Sunak's Conservative Party faces a significant defeat in the upcoming UK national election, with projections indicating they may only secure around 155 seats, while the Labour Party could win over 400 seats. If this outcome materializes, it would mark the worst electoral setback for the Tories since 1997. The survey, conducted by YouGov, employs a model that forecasts results in individual parliamentary seats based on estimated vote share. Key members of the Conservative Party, including Chancellor Jeremy Hunt and Science Minister Michelle Donelan, face uncertain fates, with the potential for several major figures to lose their seats. Despite attempts by Sunak to rebrand himself as a bold reformer, the Conservative Party has faced challenges due to controversies such as Brexit and the handling of the COVID-19 crisis. Sunak's declining popularity and pressure from within his party to adopt a more right-wing agenda further contribute to the party's struggles. The survey indicates that Sunak is still grappling to gain traction, with some Tory MPs considering replacing him with Penny Mordaunt, the current Leader of the House of Commons.

item.title: What is ‘Lavender’, the AI program that Israel ‘used’ to create kill lists in Gaza?
item.description:
The article reports on the alleged use of an AI program called Lavender by the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) to identify potential Hamas militants in Gaza following attacks in October 2023. Lavender reportedly identified over 37,000 individuals for potential air strikes. The program, developed by IDF's elite intelligence division, Unit 8200, allegedly used machine learning to assign scores to individuals based on various factors.
According to the investigation, Lavender marked individuals for potential strikes, leading to the deaths of thousands of Palestinians, including many civilians. The IDF denies using AI to generate kill lists but acknowledges Lavender's existence as a tool for analysts.
The allegations have raised concerns about civilian casualties and the IDF's targeting practices. Experts criticize the acceptance of high collateral damage ratios and stress the importance of proportionality in military actions. The article concludes with uncertainty about the duration of the conflict and potential implications for Israel.

item.title: Aam Talk: Why India's heatwaves will not impact mango production this year
item.description: India is anticipating a hotter summer this year, with the Indian Meteorological Department forecasting an increase in heatwave days due to El Nino conditions. Despite this, mango production is expected to rise to 24 million tonnes in the 2023-24 crop year, up from 21 million tonnes the previous year. Favorable weather conditions have facilitated mango flowering and fruit setting, and while heatwaves may persist, they are not anticipated to significantly impact yields. South India, which contributes 50% of the country's mango production, is expected to see bumper output. Farmers are advised to take precautions against soil moisture stress and invasive pests like thrips, which can affect fruit quality.

item.title: Lok Sabha elections 2024: Why Sanjay Singh's release is a shot in the arm for AAP
item.description: AAP leader Sanjay Singh was released from Tihar jail following bail granted by the Supreme Court in the Delhi liquor policy case. Singh's release is seen as a morale boost for the party, especially with key leaders like Arvind Kejriwal still detained. His strategic prowess and oratory skills are expected to influence the party's campaign for the upcoming Lok Sabha elections. Singh's release may also alleviate pressure on Bhagwant Mann, who has been managing AAP affairs in Kejriwal's absence. The court's decision to allow Singh to engage in political activities could impact AAP's campaign momentum positively.

item.title: NATO at 75: Is the military bloc stronger or under threat?
item.description: NATO celebrates its 75th anniversary amid renewed relevance and challenges. Originally established for collective defense against the Soviet Union, it has expanded to 32 members, including Sweden and Finland. The invasion of Ukraine by Russia in 2022 served as a wake-up call, prompting NATO to bolster its presence in Eastern Europe. Despite concerns raised by French President Emmanuel Macron about NATO's relevance, the alliance has regained purpose by refocusing on countering Moscow's aggression. However, there are fears that NATO countries could become targets if Russia prevails in Ukraine. Former US President Donald Trump's unpredictability has also cast doubts on America's commitment to NATO, though efforts to increase defense spending among member states aim to bolster the alliance's resilience. The rise of China is also becoming a focal point for NATO, seen as a way to maintain US interest and relevance within the alliance.

item.title: US treasury secretary Janet Yellen in China: What issues will she address?
item.description:
Janet Yellen, the US Treasury Secretary, is scheduled to arrive in China today, following a recent conversation between Joe Biden and Xi Jinping covering various topics. Yellen's trip is seen as a significant move in efforts to reestablish US-China relations, particularly in the realm of trade, which is considered a key driver in maintaining stable ties during a US election year.
During her visit to Guangzhou and Beijing, Yellen will engage in meetings with economists, American businesses, and local government officials. However, despite resumed talks between the two economic giants, tensions persist, particularly concerning economic issues and technological competition.
The US is wary of the potential influx of cheap Chinese exports into global markets, especially in sectors like green energy, such as solar and electric vehicles. Concerns also surround Chinese banks' substantial lending to manufacturing sectors, potentially impacting global markets and creating overcapacity issues.
Yellen is expected to address concerns raised by American firms regarding unfair treatment and market access issues in China. Moreover, there are growing national security concerns influencing economic ties, with the US implementing measures to safeguard sensitive data and monitor outbound investments involving China.
Efforts by both countries to secure critical supply chains and maintain technological supremacy have led to further tensions, including export controls and restrictions on semiconductor-related activities. Additionally, China has criticized US-led initiatives aimed at "de-risking" economies and promoting domestic industries.
Overall, Yellen's visit to China comes amid ongoing economic and technological competition, with both countries striving to assert dominance while navigating complex bilateral relations.

item.title: How Taiwan’s technology saved it from more destruction during 7.4-strong quake
item.description:
A powerful 7.4-magnitude earthquake struck Taiwan, resulting in nine deaths and numerous injuries. Despite the significant quake, Taiwan experienced relatively low casualties and damage compared to similar events in the past. This outcome can be attributed to Taiwan's implementation of stringent building codes and advanced technology.
The earthquake struck near Hualien, causing buildings to tilt and bridges to sway. Although there was damage to infrastructure and temporary disruptions to operations, including at TSMC, the world's leading microchip maker, the country quickly resumed rescue efforts. Reports indicate over a hundred people trapped in collapsed tunnels and roads.
Taiwan's earthquake preparedness is renowned globally, with experts praising its advanced infrastructure and adherence to modern seismic codes. Newer buildings, constructed with reinforced concrete and equipped with rubber bearings, fared well during the quake. Notably, Taipei 101, Taiwan's tallest building, remained intact, thanks to its tuned mass damper system.
Taiwan enforces strict penalties for those who violate building codes, deterring negligence in construction. Additionally, the country operates an early-warning system that alerts residents via mobile phones and interrupts TV broadcasts during seismic events. Public awareness and regular earthquake drills further contribute to Taiwan's resilience.
Overall, Taiwan's proactive measures and investment in earthquake preparedness have significantly reduced the impact of seismic events, highlighting the importance of robust infrastructure and public education in disaster mitigation.

item.title: NATO at 75: The key facts that define the military bloc
item.description: The NATO military alliance celebrates its 75th anniversary, formed in 1949 with 12 founding members to counter the Soviet Union. Today, it comprises 32 member countries, including recent additions like Sweden and Finland in response to Russia's aggression in Ukraine. NATO's primary goal is collective defense, with Article Five stating that an attack on one member is an attack on all. NATO's involvement in conflicts like Afghanistan and Kosovo highlights its evolving role over the years. Efforts to meet defense spending targets, particularly the commitment to spend two percent of GDP, have been ongoing, with 20 members expected to reach this goal in 2024. France's complex relationship with NATO, including a period of withdrawal, underscores the alliance's diverse membership and challenges.

item.title: FirstUp: K Kavitha's bail plea to be heard and more... The headlines today
item.description:
Today's agenda includes various events and developments across different spheres:
1. **Legal Proceedings**: - BRS MLC K Kavitha's bail plea in the liquor policy case will be heard by the Rouse Avenue Court in Delhi. She seeks temporary bail to be with her sons during their exams until April 16.
2. **Political Activities**: - Prime Minister Narendra Modi will commence the BJP's Lok Sabha poll campaign in Bihar with a rally in Jamui. - The BJP's second manifesto meeting is expected to be held, possibly focusing on promises to farmers.
3. **Global Engagements**: - Thai princess Maha Chakri Sirindhorn will visit China upon the invitation of the Chinese government.
4. **Infrastructure Notice**: - Traffic on the Mumbai-Pune expressway will be disrupted briefly for the installation of a gantry.
5. **Public Addresses**: - Union Home Minister Amit Shah will address a public meeting in Port Blair in support of a BJP candidate for the Lok Sabha elections.
6. **Legal Updates**: - The judicial custody of former Jharkhand chief minister Hemant Soren ends today in a land scam case. - Jharkhand Congress MLA Amba Prasad and her brother have been summoned by the ED for questioning in a money laundering case.
7. **Legal Proceedings in Pakistan**: - Former Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan and his wife, Bushra Bibi, are to be produced before a court in Islamabad regarding bail pleas in vandalism cases.
8. **International Election**: - Kuwait will hold parliamentary elections amid recent political turmoil.
Additionally, today marks various historical events and birthdays, including the birth anniversaries of actors Parveen Babi and Lisa Ray, poet Makhan Lal Chaturvedi, and significant historical events like the completion of New York's World Trade Center and the establishment of NATO.

item.title: Why is Botswana threatening to send 20,000 elephants to Germany?
item.description: Botswana's President Mokgweetsi Masisi has proposed sending 20,000 elephants to Germany in response to a dispute over the import of hunting trophies. Masisi argues that Botswana's elephant population has grown significantly due to conservation efforts, leading to issues such as property damage and crop destruction. He believes that hunting is necessary to control elephant numbers and maintain ecological balance. Botswana has already offered elephants to other African countries to address overpopulation concerns. Germany's environment ministry has considered stricter limits on hunting trophy imports, but Masisi warns that a ban would harm Botswana's economy. The ministry emphasizes the need for sustainable and legal import practices to protect biodiversity. Discussions within the EU are ongoing regarding potential import restrictions on protected species.

item.title: Lok Sabha elections 2024: Will it be smooth sailing for Rahul Gandhi from Wayanad again?
item.description: Rahul Gandhi filed his nomination papers from Wayanad, Kerala, a constituency he won in the 2019 Lok Sabha elections. Despite facing criticism for choosing to contest from Wayanad in addition to Amethi, Gandhi secured a record victory margin. This time, he faces CPI candidate Annie Raja and BJP's Kerala unit chief K Surendran. While Gandhi is expected to win again, his margin may decrease due to Raja's candidacy and issues such as the man-animal conflict and lack of medical infrastructure. Despite criticism for his absence in the district over the past five years, Gandhi's support remains strong, though it may not be as overwhelming as before.

item.title: Will we get a new Moon Standard Time? NASA's big plan, explained
item.description: The White House has directed NASA to establish a standardized time system for the Moon, termed Coordinated Lunar Time (LTC), to meet the precise timekeeping needs of lunar spacecraft and satellites. LTC will accommodate the slightly faster time on the Moon compared to Earth due to gravity differences. This initiative aims to set international norms in space and facilitate missions to the Moon, including NASA's Artemis program. The unified time standard will enhance data transfer security, communication synchronization, mapping accuracy, and operational coordination as commercial activities expand to the Moon. Challenges include global cooperation and agreement on timekeeping principles. Unlike time zones, time standards define time units and serve as a reference for timekeeping, with UTC being the international standard.

item.title: How pharma rivals Bharat Biotech, SII have joined forces to fight polio globally
item.description: Bharat Biotech and Serum Institute of India have partnered to strengthen the production and supply of oral polio vaccines (OPV) to combat polio globally. The collaboration aims to increase OPV production and ensure its availability, with Bharat Biotech manufacturing up to 500 million doses annually. The agreement involves sourcing the drug substance for Bharat Biotech's OPV from Serum Institute's subsidiary Bilthoven Biologicals BV. Despite a previous public dispute over COVID-19 vaccine efficacy, the two companies have reconciled to focus on eradicating polio. India's successful eradication of polio through vaccination campaigns is highlighted, with the last case reported in 2011. The article also discusses the global efforts to eradicate polio and the challenges associated with vaccine-derived poliovirus.

item.title: How the upcoming solar eclipse could cast a shadow on cell services in the US
item.description: On April 8th, a solar eclipse will sweep across North America, drawing large crowds and potentially causing disruptions, including to cell phone networks. The eclipse path will travel from Mexico to Canada, affecting 15 US states and prompting millions of people to gather to witness the event. Cell phone networks have warned of potential service issues due to the concentrated crowds overwhelming local towers. Authorities, like the New York Police Department, anticipate network overload, likening the situation to a traffic jam. Wireless carriers like Verizon and AT&T are preparing for increased usage during the eclipse, recalling past events for insight. To mitigate network congestion, officials recommend texting instead of calling and keeping communications brief. Some areas are deploying additional cellphone towers, while experts advise caution when using phones to capture eclipse images, suggesting special solar filters to protect devices.

item.title: How China has pipped the US as Southeast Asia’s most favoured ally
item.description:
A recent survey conducted by a Singapore-based think tank indicates that over 50% of respondents from Southeast Asia would prefer to align with China rather than the United States. This marks the first time since 2020 that China has emerged as the preferred choice in the region. The survey suggests that China's popularity has increased significantly, particularly in countries like Malaysia, Indonesia, and Laos, which have benefited from China's Belt and Road Initiative and strong trade relations. However, there are concerns among ASEAN countries about China's military and economic power, with about 45.5% of respondents fearing potential threats to their sovereignty.
The decline in the US's popularity in Southeast Asia is attributed to its strong support for Israel during the Gaza war, which has raised concerns among Muslim-majority nations in ASEAN. This has led to diminished confidence in US moderation and deliberation, impacting its perceived commitment to the international order.
In terms of regional influence, India lags behind China significantly, with only 0.4% of respondents considering India politically and strategically relevant to their countries. China tops the list of major powers perceived to have the most political and strategic relevance to the region, followed by the US and Japan.
Despite these dynamics, the key takeaway from the survey is that Southeast Asians prefer not to choose between the US and China. Instead, they emphasize the importance of building resilience and unity within ASEAN to navigate pressures from both superpowers.

item.title: Explained: The challenges Palestine will face in joining the UN as a full member
item.description:
The Palestinian Authority has formally requested renewed consideration by the UN Security Council of its 2011 application for full membership in the United Nations. This move, led by Palestinian UN envoy Riyad Mansour, aims to have the Security Council discuss the issue at an upcoming ministerial meeting in West Asia on April 18. However, no specific date for a vote has been set yet.
Currently, the Palestinians hold the status of a non-member observer state at the UN, similar to the Holy See. This status was upgraded in November 2012, with 138 votes in favor, nine against, and 41 abstentions.
The process for admitting new member states to the UN involves presenting an application to the UN secretary-general, who then forwards it to the Security Council for assessment and a vote. Approval requires at least nine votes in favor and no vetoes from the permanent Security Council members (US, Russia, China, France, and Britain). If approved by the Security Council, the application moves to the General Assembly, where it needs a two-thirds majority for final approval.
In 2011, the Palestinian application for full membership stalled at the Security Council due to a lack of unanimous support and the threat of a US veto. This new push seeks to revisit that decision and potentially overcome previous obstacles.

item.title: Why Texas man changed his name to Literally Anybody Else and is running for US president
item.description: A 35-year-old school math teacher from Texas has legally changed his name to "Literally Anybody Else" and is gathering signatures to run as an independent candidate in the US presidential election. He criticizes the dominance of the two-party system and aims to offer voters an alternative to the usual choices of Biden and Trump. Despite the challenging nature of his campaign, he believes it's worth pursuing to challenge the status quo. While his chances of appearing on the ballot are uncertain, he has gained some traction and hopes to gather the required signatures. Many Americans express fatigue with the usual presidential candidates and are open to new options. Although his candidacy faces obstacles, he sees his name change as a symbolic gesture of taking action rather than just complaining. He is seeking advice from experts to develop his policy agenda and has outlined some positions on his campaign website

item.title: Are Elon Musk’s antics to blame for Tesla’s dip in sales?
item.description: Tesla reported a significant drop in sales for the first quarter of the year, with global deliveries down 8.5% to 386,810 vehicles. While some attribute this decline to competition from Chinese automakers like BYD and newcomers like Xiaomi, others point to increasing competition from legacy automakers in Western countries entering the EV market. Additionally, Elon Musk's controversial behavior and polarizing image may be contributing to Tesla's reputational downfall, according to surveys and analysts. Musk's endorsement of right-wing conspiracy theories and controversial statements on social media have alienated some potential customers, leading to a decline in Tesla's consideration score among prospective buyers. Despite loyal customers like Christian Cook, who remain unfazed by Musk's actions, others believe that Musk's behavior is negatively impacting Tesla's ability to sell cars. The article concludes by noting that Musk has not commented on the matter and suggests that Tesla may announce price cuts to regain momentum, though this could affect the company's profit margins.

item.title: Black magic or suicide? What's behind the deaths of Kerala couple and friend in Arunachal?
item.description:
Three individuals from Kerala, including a married couple and a friend, were found dead in a hotel room in Arunachal Pradesh's Ziro. The police recovered their bodies from Hotel Blue Pine at Hapoli, where they appeared to have bled to death from cuts on their wrists. The deceased were identified as Naveen Thomas and his wife Devi, both Ayurvedic doctors, and Arya B Nair, a schoolteacher. A suicide note was found in their room, stating they had no debts or problems and were going "to the place where we should be."
The incident came to light when Arya's father filed a missing complaint. There are suspicions of black magic involvement, as the couple was associated with an organization called 'Punarjani,' which allegedly deals with dark forces. The couple had reportedly stopped their Ayurvedic practice and started online trading. Investigations are ongoing, with Kerala police planning to send a team to Arunachal Pradesh to gather more evidence. However, the exact cause of death has not been determined

item.title: AAP says Arvind Kejriwal’s health worsening in Tihar jail: Is it true?
item.description:
The Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) has raised concerns about the health of Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal, stating that he has lost over four kilograms since his arrest by the Enforcement Directorate (ED) in a graft case on 21st March. Atishi, a Delhi minister and senior AAP leader, emphasized that Kejriwal, who suffers from severe diabetes, has experienced fluctuations in his sugar levels while in custody, reaching dangerously low levels. The AAP has expressed worry over his deteriorating health and has highlighted the issue amid legal proceedings challenging his arrest.
However, Tihar jail officials have refuted claims regarding Kejriwal's health, stating that his weight remains unchanged and his sugar levels are now normal. They have provided him with necessary medical care and a sugar sensor to monitor his levels, along with home-cooked meals and emergency support in his cell. Additionally, the Enforcement Directorate asserted that they took adequate measures to ensure Kejriwal's well-being during his custody.
Concerns have also arisen regarding Kejriwal's safety within the jail, with reports suggesting potential threats from other inmates. In response, guards are on alert to safeguard him. Delhi ministers have emphasized the importance of protecting Kejriwal's life, underscoring its significance for the country.

item.title: How World Central Kitchen's Jose Andres fought bureaucracy to bring aid to Gaza
item.description: The World Central Kitchen (WCK), led by celebrity chef Jose Andres, has been actively involved in humanitarian efforts in Gaza. Despite tragic losses, including seven workers killed in an Israeli airstrike, WCK has continued its aid missions, collaborating with the Spanish charity Open Arms to deliver food aid via a maritime corridor from Cyprus. This initiative arose after Israel refused to allow the UN Palestinian refugee agency to deliver food to northern Gaza. WCK has also navigated bureaucratic obstacles to provide aid, demonstrating a commitment to expediently feeding people in crisis situations. While operations are currently suspended, WCK remains dedicated to its mission of providing emergency aid in conflict zones and disaster areas worldwide.

item.title: Taiwan struck by 7.4 magnitude earthquake: Why the island is prone to temblors
item.description: A powerful 7.4-magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of Taiwan, the strongest in a quarter century, resulting in four deaths and dozens of injuries. The epicenter was in Hualien, where at least 26 buildings were damaged. Landslides and aftershocks followed, causing significant destruction and disrupting transportation services across the island. Despite the impact, Taiwan's nuclear power stations remained unaffected. The earthquake also triggered a tsunami warning for southern Japanese islands and the Philippines, though no major tsunami occurred. Taiwan, located along the Pacific "Ring of Fire," frequently experiences earthquakes, with the last major one occurring in 2018. The deadliest quake in Taiwan's history was the 1999 Chi-Chi quake, which killed thousands and prompted improvements in disaster relief and early warning systems.

item.title: What is the Rolex watch scandal threatening Peru's president Dina Boluarte?
item.description: Peru's President Dina Boluarte is embroiled in a scandal over her possession of luxury watches, including Rolex timepieces, without a clear explanation of how she acquired them. The investigation has expanded to include a Cartier bracelet and bank deposits of unknown origin. Boluarte, Peru's first female president, faces allegations of illicit enrichment, with police raiding her residence and the presidential palace for evidence. Despite her denial of wrongdoing, documents linking her to luxury items have been discovered. The scandal has led to calls for her resignation or impeachment, with her approval rating plummeting. The situation reflects Peru's history of political turmoil and corruption scandals involving its leaders.

item.title: How the death of World Central Kitchen workers in Israel airstrike imperils Gaza aid
item.description:
The article discusses the tragic death of seven aid workers from World Central Kitchen (WCK) in an Israeli airstrike in Gaza. Despite coordination with the Israeli Defense Forces (IDF), the convoy was hit as it left a warehouse after unloading humanitarian aid. The victims included individuals from various nationalities, highlighting the international scope of humanitarian efforts. The incident has led to condemnation worldwide and raised questions about the safety of aid deliveries in conflict zones.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu described the incident as unintentional, promising a thorough investigation. However, the deaths have led to a suspension of WCK's operations in Gaza and prompted other charities to halt their activities due to safety concerns. The attack exacerbates the dire humanitarian situation in Gaza, where thousands face famine.
This tragedy underscores the risks faced by aid workers in conflict zones and raises concerns about Israel's international standing. With increasing condemnation, Israel risks losing support from its allies and faces pressure to address the humanitarian crisis in Gaza

item.title: FirstUp: Kejriwal's plea to be heard, Rahul Gandhi to file nomination in Wayanad: The news today
item.description: The Delhi High Court is set to hear CM Arvind Kejriwal's plea against his arrest in an alleged excise policy case, while Rahul Gandhi is expected to file his nomination in Wayanad. Additionally, the RBI's first monetary policy meeting of the year will commence, with the decision to be announced by April 5. Heatwave alerts have been issued for certain regions in India, and Sumalatha Ambareesh will announce her decision on contesting from Mandya. Moreover, Andhra Pradesh will see the launch of its first human milk bank.

item.title: No Child's Play: Why is adopting a child a tough task in India?
item.description: India has achieved a milestone in adoptions, surpassing 4,000 adoptions between April 2023 and March 2024, with 3,560 adoptions within India and 449 inter-country adoptions. However, there are significant challenges in the adoption process, including a lengthy and complex procedure that takes at least two years, limited availability of legally adoptable children compared to the number of prospective parents, and societal stigmas surrounding adoption. Despite efforts to expedite the process, concerns remain about the welfare and safety of the children involved. Additionally, there is a need for campaigns to encourage the adoption of older children and those with special needs

item.title: India to face extreme heat between April-June: Will it affect voter turnout?
item.description: The India Meteorological Department (IMD) has issued a warning of extreme heatwaves in India between April and June, with central and western regions expected to be most affected. This coincides with the Lok Sabha elections and Assembly elections in four states. Concerns arise about voter turnout due to the scorching temperatures, especially in severely affected areas. The Election Commission of India (ECI) has advised measures to ensure voter safety, including setting up polling booths on the ground floor for elderly and disabled voters, providing amenities like shade and drinking water, and distributing handbills on heatstroke prevention. Voters are encouraged to stay hydrated, avoid tight clothing, and cast their ballots in the cooler morning hours.

item.title: How Byju's is laying off hundreds of workers with just phone calls
item.description: Byju’s, an edtech company, is making headlines for laying off hundreds of employees via phone calls without placing them on performance improvement plans or providing notice periods. The layoffs are part of a business restructuring exercise announced last year. Additionally, the company is facing delays in salary disbursement due to an interim order obtained by some investors, restricting fund usage. Byju’s management is hopeful of resolving the issue through legal means. item.title: Can India reclaim Katchatheevu island from Sri Lanka?
item.description:
The BJP has stirred controversy in Tamil Nadu by making the Katchatheevu island issue a key topic ahead of the Lok Sabha elections. The island, traditionally a fishing ground for both Indian and Sri Lankan fishermen, has been a source of dispute since the 1920s. In 1974, then PM Indira Gandhi signed an agreement ceding the island to Sri Lanka, sparking ongoing tension, particularly when Indian fishermen are arrested or mistreated by the Sri Lankan Navy.
The BJP's Tamil Nadu chief claims the Indian government is seeking to reclaim Katchatheevu, a move supported by EAM Jaishankar. However, Sri Lanka denies any official communication from India on this matter. Legal experts argue that reclaiming the island would likely require military action, as unilateral withdrawal from agreements under UNCLOS is not feasible. Additionally, such a move could damage India's international reputation and provoke legal action from Sri Lanka.
In summary, while the BJP's stance on Katchatheevu may appeal to some voters in Tamil Nadu, the practicality and potential consequences of reclaiming the island remain uncertain.
