The bill requires ByteDance, TikTok's owner, to divest its stakes in the app or face a ban. This move is seen as a major threat to TikTok, which has a large user base of over 170 million in the US. The bill, known as the Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act, was introduced due to national security concerns over TikTok's data practices and its Chinese ownership.
The bill has now moved to the Senate for consideration, and while its future is uncertain, President Joe Biden has indicated he would sign it into law if it reaches his desk. The administration is urging the Senate to act quickly on the matter.
TikTok has tried to alleviate concerns by stating that US user data is stored in Singapore and the US, not China, and that it would not share data with the Chinese government. However, US lawmakers remain unconvinced, and TikTok's CEO, Shou Zi Chew, has faced intense questioning by Congress.
If the bill becomes law, it would prevent app stores from distributing or updating TikTok, and web hosting companies from supporting it, which would eventually render the app obsolete for US users. This could have significant repercussions for small businesses and content creators who rely on the platform for income.
The article also touches on the broader implications for TikTok users, who may have to seek alternatives, and the potential for users to circumvent a ban using VPNs. The situation remains fluid, with the tech community and TikTok users closely watching the developments.

item.title: All work, no play: Why fewer Chinese students are taking sport, music lessons
item.description:
The article discusses the impact of China's economic downturn on the spending habits of middle-class families, particularly regarding after-school activities for children. With the economy struggling, marked by a stock market downturn, heavy debt in the property sector, and job cuts, families are cutting back on non-essential expenses. This includes extracurricular activities such as sports and music lessons, which were once common expenditures for families with an only child.
The financial strain is evident as parents now opt to pay for one class at a time instead of committing to long-term lesson packages. The article highlights the story of Zhang Zhaolin, who had to withdraw her son from soccer classes after losing her job, and piano teacher Liu Hongyu, whose student count has halved, leading her to downsize her school and staff.
The 2021 crackdown on the private-sector tutoring industry, aimed at reducing homework and education costs, has inadvertently affected extracurricular activities. With schools extending hours to compensate for the closure of tutoring centers, parents find less need for additional classes, further impacting businesses that offer these activities.
Overall, the economic challenges and policy changes have reshaped priorities and led to a significant reduction in spending on children's after-school activities in China.

item.title: FirstUp: Bhutan's PM in India, Farmers' mahapanchayat in Delhi.... Top news today
item.description:
Here's a summary of the key events and news from the article:
- **Bhutan's Prime Minister Tshering Tobgay** is starting a **five-day visit to India**, which is his first foreign trip since taking office in January. He will engage in talks with Indian officials, including Prime Minister Narendra Modi and President Droupadi Murmu, and visit Mumbai. - The **Samyukta Kisan Morcha (SKM)** is organizing the 'Kisan Mahapanchayat' at Delhi's Ramlila ground, expecting over 50,000 farmers from Punjab. Delhi police have provided necessary clearances and amenities for the event. - The **dates for the upcoming Lok Sabha elections** are likely to be announced, with the Election Commission having conducted a briefing meeting to ensure the implementation of the model code of conduct. - A **prime minister-led panel** will meet to select two new Election Commissioners to fill recent vacancies. - **Congress leader Rahul Gandhi** will hold a roadshow in Nashik as part of his Bharat Jodo Nyay Yatra and visit the Trimbakeshwar temple. - A **Delhi court** is set to decide on the CBI's supplementary charge sheet in the Railways' land-for-job case involving RJD chief Lalu Prasad Yadav and others. - **SpaceX** is planning the third test flight of its Starship megarocket, which could advance NASA's lunar ambitions and the commercial spaceflight industry. - **Union Minister Amit Shah** will inaugurate the office premises of the National Investigation Agency (NIA) via video conferencing.
Additionally, the article mentions the birth anniversaries of notable individuals such as actor Aamir Khan, physicist Albert Einstein, and film director Rohit Shetty, as well as historical events like the patent grant for the cotton gin and the release of India's first talking film, 'Alam Ara'.

item.title: ‘Sephora kids’: Why obsession of tweens with skincare is concerning
item.description: The article discusses the "Sephora Kids" trend, where children and young teens are showing a keen interest in expensive cosmetics and skincare routines, sharing their experiences on social media platforms like TikTok and Instagram. Dermatologists express concern over the potential harm these products, which are not designed for young skin, can cause, including skin barrier damage, dermatitis, and acne. The trend is also leading to a significant increase in sales for beauty brands, some of which are now targeting the younger demographic, known as Gen Alpha, with products and marketing strategies. Brands are leveraging social media influencers and algorithms to reach and influence tweens, who are increasingly concerned about their appearance. The baby and child skincare market is expected to grow substantially, with a projected global market volume of $380 million by 2028. The article highlights the implications of this trend on children's health and the beauty industry's direction.

item.title: Opinion Poll: How Modi, jobs and inflation will be the key factors for 2024
item.description:
The News18 mega opinion poll ahead of the 2024 Lok Sabha elections indicates a strong approval for Prime Minister Narendra Modi and the BJP, with **80%** of respondents expressing satisfaction with their performance. The poll suggests that Modi is particularly popular among the youth, with high approval ratings in the 18-35 age group.
Modi's perceived honesty, hard work, and strong leadership qualities are highlighted as his key strengths. In contrast, opposition leaders like Rahul Gandhi, Arvind Kejriwal, and Mamata Banerjee received significantly lower approval ratings.
Economically, **67%** of those polled believe their status has improved over the past five years, and **72%** are optimistic about the future. Social issues such as the construction of the Ram Mandir and the Women's Reservation Bill also received substantial support.
The poll also reflects a positive view of Modi's welfare schemes, with the Ujwala Yojana being the most recognized. State government performances varied, with high satisfaction in BJP-ruled Uttar Pradesh and lower satisfaction in Maharashtra and Delhi.
The Modi factor appears to be a significant influence on BJP's electoral success, with **85%** willing to vote for the party regardless of the local candidate. The opposition's INDIA alliance is known to **56%** of respondents, but its leaders are less popular compared to Modi.
Key voter concerns include job creation, inflation, law and order, corruption, and religion. The survey underscores Modi's dominance in Indian politics and the challenges faced by the opposition in the upcoming elections.

item.title: Files in pen drive, password in envelope: How SBI submitted data on electoral bonds to EC
item.description: The State Bank of India (SBI) complied with the Supreme Court's directive by submitting data on electoral bonds to the Election Commission (EC). The data, stored in two password-protected PDF files on a pen drive, detailed the purchase and redemption of electoral bonds from April 2019 to February 2024. A total of 22,217 bonds were issued, with 22,030 redeemed and the remaining funds directed to the Prime Minister's national relief fund as per the scheme's rules. The SBI provided the EC with comprehensive details, including dates, denominations, and names of political parties involved in the transactions. Despite a tight deadline and the logistical challenge of collating data from various branches, SBI managed to deliver the information promptly. The EC is expected to make this data public, adhering to the principles of transparency. The Supreme Court had previously declared electoral bonds unconstitutional and ordered an immediate halt to their issuance.

item.title: Meet Hyodol, the AI doll that helps old adults beat loneliness in South Korea
item.description:
To address the growing concern of loneliness, particularly among the elderly, a South Korean company has developed an AI-powered robot doll named Hyodol. Designed to interact with seniors, especially those with dementia, Hyodol offers companionship through advanced language processing, emotional recognition, and entertainment features like music. The robot can be monitored remotely by caregivers, who can also use an app to check in and communicate with the user. Priced at $1,800, around 7,000 units have been deployed by the South Korean government to assist seniors with daily reminders and health monitoring.
The development of Hyodol is a response to South Korea's rapidly aging population, which is expected to become a super-aged society by 2025. With a significant portion of the elderly living alone and experiencing social isolation, the country faces a loneliness epidemic. This demographic shift is impacting the nation's care industry, labor force, and economy.
Hyodol is part of a broader trend of using technology to combat loneliness. Other examples include NAO, a humanoid robot developed in Kazakhstan to assist children with autism, and ElliQ, an Israeli invention that helps reduce social isolation among the elderly. These innovations reflect a global issue, with loneliness being recognized as a significant health concern worldwide. The American Psychological Association describes loneliness as a state of discomfort from feeling solitary, and reports suggest that billions globally experience loneliness, with serious health implications. Countries like Ireland and Sweden have high rates of people living alone, indicating the scale of this challenge.

item.title: India wants to ban Pit bulls, Rottweilers: How dangerous are these dog breeds?
item.description:
Following a series of dog attacks in India, the government is considering a ban on the import, breeding, and sale of certain dog breeds deemed dangerous. The breeds in question include Pit bulls, Rottweilers, Terriers, Wolf Dogs, and Mastiffs, as well as their crossbred and mixed variants. This action is a response to numerous incidents where these dogs have caused serious injuries or fatalities.
The Department of Animal Husbandry and Dairying has advised states not to issue licenses for the sale or breeding of these breeds, following an expert committee's report and a Delhi High Court ruling. The court has also directed the Union of India to consult all stakeholders and decide on the matter promptly.
Recent attacks have prompted local bans in various Indian cities, with some municipalities imposing restrictions on dog ownership, such as limiting the number of pet dogs per family and requiring licenses. The breeds have been controversial due to their aggressive history and have been banned or restricted in several countries worldwide.
The article details several severe attacks by these breeds in India, leading to significant injuries and, in some cases, legal action against the dog owners. It also discusses the contentious nature of these breeds, their historical roles, and the debate over whether their aggressive behavior is innate or due to upbringing. The article concludes by noting that these breeds are banned or restricted in many countries due to their aggressive tendencies.

item.title: Is China falling out of love with Apple and Tesla?
item.description:
In China, there's a significant shift in consumer preferences from American tech giants like Apple and Tesla to local brands. Apple's iPhone sales have dropped sharply, with its market share falling to 15.7%, as Chinese consumers opt for domestic brands like Huawei, Oppo, Vivo, and Xiaomi. This trend is bolstered by a resurgence of Huawei, particularly after the launch of its Mate 60 smartphone. The decline in Apple's popularity is partly due to a government-led initiative to reduce iPhone usage among state employees and a broader push for nationalism.
Tesla is also experiencing challenges, with a 22% drop in revenue and decreased shipments from its Shanghai gigafactory. The electric vehicle (EV) market in China is slowing down, and Tesla faces competition from local EV manufacturers like BYD, which reported a 43% rise in sales and price cuts on its models. Xiaomi's entry into the EV market with its SU7 vehicles adds to Tesla's competition.
Overall, foreign companies like Apple and Tesla are witnessing a decline in sales as Chinese consumers increasingly support local brands, a trend that is expected to impact American market control in China. This shift is part of a larger movement in China to promote domestic products over foreign ones, especially in technology and energy sectors.

item.title: Nepal got rid of monarchy 16 years ago. Why do they want it back now?
item.description:
In Nepal, a significant number of citizens are demonstrating in Kathmandu with demands to abolish the republic and reinstate the monarchy. This movement is driven by dissatisfaction with the current political system, which has seen 13 different governments in the past 16 years, and allegations of corruption and poor governance by the major political parties.
The protests reflect a growing nostalgia for the stability perceived during the monarchy, especially under King Gyanendra, who was dethroned 16 years ago after a mass movement against his absolute rule. Despite the abolition of the monarchy in 2008, there is a visible increase in pro-monarchy sentiment, with larger rallies and public displays of the former king's portraits.
Critics of the current system argue that politicians are more focused on power than solving the country's problems, leading to a struggling economy and widespread corruption. The Rastriya Prajatantra Party, a supporter of the monarchy, holds a minority in parliament but has been vocal about its demands, claiming that the restoration of the monarchy is essential for the country's future and identity.
However, the major political parties firmly reject the possibility of reinstating the monarchy, stating that it would require a constitutional change, which they see as highly unlikely. The former king has remained largely out of politics since his abdication, and while the pro-monarchy movement is gaining momentum, analysts believe it is still too small to effect immediate change. The article concludes with insights from various political analysts and party representatives, reflecting the complex sentiments surrounding the monarchy in Nepal.

item.title: California Girls: Inside the women's gang that stole $8 million in cosmetics across US
item.description: Michelle Mack, a 53-year-old mother of three, was arrested for leading a theft ring known as "California Girls." She orchestrated the theft of over $8 million in makeup and clothing from various stores across the US, selling the items on Amazon. The operation was run from her San Diego mansion, where she recruited women to commit the thefts and then sold the stolen goods online. The scheme was uncovered when two shoplifters were arrested, leading to the discovery of Mack's operation. California Attorney General Rob Bonta has filed 140 felony charges against Mack and her accomplices. The case highlights the issue of organized retail crime in the US, which has significant financial and human impacts on communities and businesses. Authorities are taking steps to combat this growing problem, with marketplaces like Amazon aiding in the crackdown on the sale of stolen goods.

item.title: Biden classified documents case: 6 key takeaways from Robert Hur's testimony
item.description:
Special Counsel Robert Hur testified before the House Judiciary Committee regarding his investigation into President Joe Biden's handling of classified information. Hur's report described Biden as a well-meaning individual with a poor memory but did not recommend charges. The hearing involved intense questioning from both parties, with Democrats accusing Hur of partisanship and Republicans questioning the decision not to prosecute. Hur emphasized that his investigation was apolitical and that he could not prove criminal intent beyond a reasonable doubt.
The hearing contrasted the cases of Biden and former President Donald Trump, highlighting the differences in their handling of classified documents. Biden cooperated with the investigation, while Trump is accused of obstruction and mishandling classified information.
Discussion also focused on the legal requirements for prosecuting mishandling of classified information, particularly the need for wilful intent, which Hur did not find sufficient evidence of in Biden's case.
The hearing and Biden's interview transcript revealed the president's occasional lapses in memory but also his detailed recollections of personal and political events. Despite this, the hearing largely became a platform for partisan attacks, with both sides using it to criticize the opposing party's presidential candidate. The session is unlikely to change entrenched public perceptions of either Biden or Trump.

item.title: US will not ban TikTok if it finds a new owner: Why is that easier said than done?
item.description: The article discusses a bill in the US House of Representatives that would require ByteDance to sell TikTok or face a ban in the US. The bill is gaining traction despite opposition from former President Donald Trump. The bill aims to address national security concerns over China's potential access to data through ByteDance. It allows for TikTok to operate in the US if ByteDance divests and cuts all ties, including data sharing and algorithm cooperation. The sale of TikTok presents challenges due to its high value and potential antitrust scrutiny. The bill could lower TikTok's sale price as it approaches a six-month deadline. The bill is unique in targeting a single company and would require presidential approval for a "qualified divestiture." The situation echoes a 2020 deal involving Oracle and Walmart, which was never completed. President Biden supports the bill, while Trump does not. The summary omits unrelated content as per your request.

item.title: How Canada’s charge of India’s role in Nijjar killing has fallen flat
item.description:
The article discusses the skepticism expressed by New Zealand's Deputy Prime Minister Winston Peters regarding Canada's claim of India's involvement in the assassination of Hardeep Singh Nijjar. Peters, who is also the Foreign Minister of New Zealand, questioned the evidence provided by Canada during his visit to New Delhi. The 'Five Eyes' intelligence alliance, which includes the US, UK, Australia, New Zealand, and Canada, had previously shared intelligence that led Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to allege India's involvement. However, Peters noted the absence of concrete evidence to support the claim.
The article also mentions that India has firmly denied the allegations, which have strained India-Canada relations. Despite the claims, no information has been shared with India, and the investigation by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police continues without any arrests. Recently released security footage shows the alleged killers of Nijjar, but the case remains unresolved.
This summary omits unrelated content and focuses on the key points of the article.

item.title: FirstUp: Modi to lay foundation stone of chip plants in Gujarat, Nepal PM seeks 3rd vote of confidence... Big news today
item.description:
Here's a summary of the key points from the article:
- **Prime Minister Narendra Modi** will lay the foundation stone for three semiconductor projects in Gujarat, aiming to make India a global hub for semiconductor design and manufacturing. The projects are valued at approximately Rs 1.25 lakh crore. - **Nepal’s Prime Minister Pushpa Kamal Dahal 'Prachanda'** is seeking his third vote of confidence in Parliament after forming a new alliance with the CPN-UML. - The **second Vande Bharat Express** between Secunderabad and Visakhapatnam, and the fourth from Telangana, will commence operations. - The **Supreme Court** is set to hear BRS leader K Kavitha’s plea against the Enforcement Directorate's summons in the Delhi excise policy irregularities case. - The **Allahabad High Court** will hear a plea concerning the maintainability of the suit seeking the removal of the Shahi Idgah mosque adjacent to the Krishna Janmabhoomi temple in Mathura. - A **job fair** is being organized in Chhapra, Bihar, for various positions, offering good salaries and facilities to successful candidates. - Historical events and anniversaries, including the discovery of Uranus and significant events in Mumbai, are also mentioned.
This summary excludes any unrelated content or advertisements that may have been present in the original article.

item.title: The Taylor Swift effect: How vinyl records returned to UK inflation basket after 32 years
item.description: Vinyl records have been reintroduced to the UK's inflation basket for the first time since 1992, reflecting their resurgence in popularity, partly driven by Taylor Swift's album sales. The Office for National Statistics (ONS) updated its basket to include vinyl records among 744 items used to measure inflation. This change highlights the cultural revival's impact on consumer spending. Vinyl records' inclusion comes after a significant sales boost, with 6.1 million units sold in the UK last year, the highest since 1990. The format's growth is supported by younger generations and has led to an increase in independent record stores. Other new items in the inflation basket include air fryers, healthier cooking oil spray, and sunflower and pumpkin seeds, indicating a shift towards healthier living. Conversely, hand sanitiser and other pandemic-related items have been removed due to decreased demand. These updates will be reflected in the inflation release on 20 March.

item.title: How more and more Chinese are illegally entering the US through the southern border
item.description:
The article discusses the significant increase in Chinese migrants crossing into the United States via the southern border, with numbers nearly tenfold higher in 2023 compared to 2022. This surge is attributed to a combination of a slowing Chinese economy, stricter political control under President Xi Jinping, and readily available information on Chinese social media about emigration methods.
The closure of the Darien Gap, a dangerous jungle passage between South and Central America, briefly interrupted one of the busiest migration routes but underscored its importance, especially for Chinese migrants. While a record 2.5 million migrants were detained at the US southwestern border in 2023, only about 37,000 were from China.
Journalists note that these migrants are predominantly from the self-employed middle class, who are not wealthy enough to migrate through education or work opportunities but can afford international travel. Many are small-business owners affected by China's "zero COVID" policies. The increase in migration is partly due to the difficulty of obtaining immigrant visas and the temporary halt in migration during the pandemic's early travel restrictions.
Social media platforms like Douyin and TikTok have become sources of information for potential migrants, offering guides on visa-free travel and border crossing. This has led to a significant number of Chinese migrants traveling to Ecuador, which allows visa-free entry for Chinese citizens, and then journeying to the US-Mexican border, often through the perilous Darien Gap.
The article also touches on the historical context of Chinese migration to the US, dating back to when Chinese laborers were banned from immigrating, leading many to enter illegally. Despite the end of exclusion laws, Chinese migrants without the necessary education or family connections continued to seek dangerous routes with the help of smugglers.
Currently, Chinese asylum seekers have a higher success rate in their claims compared to other nationalities, often citing political oppression and lack of religious freedom. The article concludes by suggesting that the increase in Chinese migration could become a political issue in the upcoming US election, potentially exacerbating tensions between the US and China. The article is authored by Meredith Oyen, an Associate Professor of History and Asian Studies.

item.title: Climate change can drive up banana prices: Will India be affected?
item.description: Bananas, a vital source of nutrition and income worldwide, are facing significant threats from climate change and crop diseases, particularly the Fusarium Wilt TR4, which could result in increased prices. The World Banana Forum is addressing these challenges and seeking sustainable production methods. Rising temperatures facilitate disease spread, with the TR4 strain posing a severe risk to the Cavendish variety. Factors like severe weather, high fertilizer costs, energy and transport expenses, and labor shortages contribute to declining banana exports and potential price hikes. India, the largest producer and consumer of bananas, has already seen price inflation due to these issues. A study predicts that climate change may reverse the gains in banana yields made since the 1960s, with countries like India and Brazil likely to experience reduced yields, while others like Ecuador may see increases. The global banana trade's decline could significantly impact developing countries' economies.

item.title: Why bosses in China could be penalised for ‘invisible overtime’
item.description:
China is considering legal protection for employees against "invisible overtime," which refers to work done online outside of regular working hours. This initiative follows recommendations from political advisor Lyu Guoquan, who urged the creation of guidelines and a legal framework to address this issue. The European Union defines "the right to disconnect" as the ability of workers to disengage from work-related communications after hours. Lyu highlighted the negative impact of being "always online" on workers' well-being and suggested limiting hours for certain jobs, amending work hours to include online overtime, and penalizing companies that enforce unpaid overtime.
The Supreme People's Court of China supports the proposal, with Chief Justice Zhang Jun emphasizing the need to reward online work and protect offline rest. Past discussions and court cases in China have addressed overtime payments, with the Supreme Court citing a case where a director sued for unpaid overtime due to work-related communication on WeChat after hours. Lou Yu, a legal expert, believes regulations on online overtime labor are likely but may take years to implement.
Globally, the issue of unpaid overtime is prevalent, with many countries considering legislation to limit employer contact outside of work hours. The UK, Singapore, and Australia are among those addressing unpaid overtime, with Europe leading the way in implementing "the right to disconnect" policies. However, countries like the US, the UK, and India are still behind in tackling this work-life balance challenge. The article concludes with a note on the widespread discussion of invisible overtime and its impact on employees worldwide.

item.title: Manohar Lal Khattar out, Nayab Singh Saini in: What’s happening in Haryana?
item.description: In Haryana, a significant political shift occurred with the resignation of Chief Minister Manohar Lal Khattar and the dissolution of the BJP-JJP alliance. The BJP chose Nayab Singh Saini, the MP from Kurukshetra, as the new Chief Minister. The split was primarily due to disagreements over seat-sharing for the upcoming Lok Sabha elections, particularly concerning the Hisar and Bhiwani-Mahendragarh constituencies. The BJP's refusal to concede these seats to the JJP, despite the latter's strong claims, led to the alliance's breakdown. The BJP's decision to move forward without the JJP aims to address anti-incumbency sentiments and influence the Jat vote in the upcoming elections. The political landscape in Haryana remains uncertain, especially for the JJP and its members, some of whom may switch allegiance to the BJP. The BJP now appears to have secured support from five Independent MLAs, which could impact the party's position in both the Lok Sabha and Assembly elections.

item.title: In a first, a daughter to become Pakistan’s first lady: Who is Aseefa Bhutto Zardari?
item.description:
Aseefa Bhutto Zardari, the youngest daughter of Pakistan's former president Asif Ali Zardari and late prime minister Benazir Bhutto, is likely to be appointed as the country's first lady. This marks a departure from tradition as the role is typically assumed by the president's wife. Aseefa, 31, is known for her work in polio eradication and has been politically active, campaigning for her brother Bilawal and appearing alongside her father.
Aseefa holds a master's degree in public health and has been a prominent figure since her youth, including meeting Nobel laureate Malala Yousafzai. Her political involvement increased with her debut at a rally in 2020, and she has since been a key figure in the Pakistan People's Party (PPP), particularly during the recent electoral campaign.
If confirmed as first lady, Aseefa is expected to engage in traditional roles such as hosting events and supporting domestic initiatives. She would follow in the footsteps of her grandmother Nusrat Bhutto, who was also an active political figure. The appointment of daughters as first ladies is unprecedented in Pakistan, though there have been similar instances in the United States. An official announcement regarding Aseefa's appointment is pending.

item.title: Why is Airbnb banning the use of indoor security cameras?
item.description: Airbnb has announced a new policy that will ban the use of indoor security cameras in properties listed on the platform. This change, which aims to simplify security camera policies and enhance guest privacy, will take effect on **30th April**. The policy was developed with input from guests, hosts, and privacy experts, and Airbnb will continue to seek feedback for policy improvement. While indoor cameras will be prohibited, doorbell cameras and noise decibel monitors are still allowed for security and monitoring unauthorized parties. Hosts must disclose any outdoor cameras and ensure they do not invade private areas. The policy update follows social media complaints about hidden cameras and a related spoof on Saturday Night Live. Hosts have until the deadline to comply, and failure to do so may result in listing removal or account suspension. The policy is expected to affect a minority of listings, as most do not report having security cameras.

item.title: Matuas in Bengal hail CAA implementation: Who are they? How will they gain from the law?
item.description: The Matua community, primarily Hindu migrants from Bangladesh, celebrated the implementation of the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) in West Bengal. The CAA, passed by the Indian Parliament in 2019, aims to provide Indian citizenship to non-Muslim refugees from Bangladesh, Pakistan, and Afghanistan. This move is significant as it comes ahead of the Lok Sabha elections, with the Matuas' vote potentially influencing eight seats in Bengal. The BJP hopes this will secure the Matua vote, while the TMC criticizes the timing of the Act's notification. The Matuas, who have a substantial population in Bengal, have a history of political involvement and could impact around 70 Assembly seats. The CAA's implementation fulfills a long-standing demand of the community, providing them fast-track citizenship and ending their status as refugees. The Matua community's response was jubilant, with celebrations at their spiritual center in Thakurnagar. Political figures have hailed this as a historic day for refugees, while the TMC raises concerns about the implications for those who may lack documentation to prove their citizenship. The BJP's internal survey suggests that the CAA could affect electoral outcomes in several Lok Sabha constituencies in Bengal.

item.title: Can you go to jail for not filing your income tax returns?
item.description: A Delhi Court has sentenced a woman, identified as Savitri, to six months in jail for not filing an income tax return on an income of Rs 2 crore. The Income Tax Office (ITO) had issued multiple notices to Savitri, which she failed to respond to, leading to her conviction. The court considered her circumstances as an uneducated widow with no family support and granted her 30 days' bail to appeal the decision. The case highlights the importance of filing income tax returns and the potential legal consequences of failing to do so, including penalties and imprisonment. Taxpayers are advised to file their returns on time to avoid such penalties and are provided with options to file updated returns or request a condonation for delay in certain circumstances. The article also explains the process and requirements for filing income tax returns in India.

item.title: Amid gang violence, Haiti PM Henry Ariel resigns: What happens next?
item.description: Haiti's Prime Minister Ariel Henry has announced his resignation amid escalating gang violence and political turmoil. He stated he will step down once a transitional presidential council is formed. The country has been plagued by gang rampages, including attacks on prisons, shops, and government buildings, leading to the evacuation of diplomats by the US and EU. The gangs, led by ex-police officer Jimmy "Barbecue" Chérizier, aim to overthrow Henry, whom they view as unelected and not representative of the people's aspirations. Henry's interim successor will be chosen by a seven-member presidential council, with decisions made by majority vote. Additionally, an international stabilization force led by Kenya will be deployed to restore order, backed by a $100 million pledge from the US. Guy Philippe, a former coup leader, has expressed his intention to run for president. The situation remains volatile as Haiti approaches the brink of becoming a failed state.

item.title: Mumbai coastal road now open: How it will benefit the city
item.description: The Mumbai Coastal Road Project's south-bound section was inaugurated by Maharashtra CM Eknath Shinde, promising reduced travel time, congestion, and pollution, while also boosting real estate. The project includes a 53-km road linked to the Bandra-Worli Sea Link, extending to Dahisar, built at an estimated cost of Rs 12,721 crore. Named after Dharmaveer Sambhaji Maharaj, the route features tunnels, interchanges, and a speed limit of 80 km/h. It's expected to save fuel and time, especially during peak hours, and reduce carbon footprints by 34%. The real estate market is anticipated to benefit significantly, with reduced travel times rejuvenating business hubs and driving residential demand. The next phase will connect Versova and Dahisar, with completion expected by May 2024. The project aims to create a ring road connecting suburban Mumbai with the island city and satellite districts.

item.title: Will France legalise assisted dying? Which other European countries allow it?
item.description:
French President Emmanuel Macron has announced a new bill to legalize 'aid in dying' for adults with terminal illnesses and intractable pain, expected to die in the short to middle term. The law, which will undergo a legislative process starting in May, sets conditions such as the exclusion of those with severe psychiatric or neurodegenerative disorders. This move follows a report indicating majority support among French citizens for legalizing end-of-life options.
The article also compares France's proposed legislation with laws in other European countries. The Netherlands was the first to legalize active euthanasia and assisted suicide in 2002, later extending it to minors with parental consent and patients with severe dementia. Belgium, Luxembourg, Spain, and Portugal have similar laws, with Belgium allowing euthanasia for terminally ill children of any age. Switzerland, while prohibiting euthanasia, permits assisted suicide, leading to 'suicide tourism.' Austria legalized assisted suicide in 2022, and Italy's constitutional court ruled that assisting suicide should not always be punishable. The UK is experiencing renewed interest in the debate over assisted dying.
The summary omits unrelated content and focuses on the key points of the proposed legislation and its context within European euthanasia and assisted suicide laws.

item.title: After four years, CAA implemented: What changes and what doesn’t?
item.description:
The Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) of 2019, which was passed by the Indian Parliament, has been officially notified after four years. The act facilitates the citizenship process for non-Muslim migrants from Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Afghanistan who face persecution. It specifies that the CAA does not affect existing Indian citizens.
The CAA allows Hindus, Sikhs, Buddhists, Jains, Parsis, and Christians from the aforementioned countries, who arrived in India on or before December 31, 2014, to fast-track their citizenship process. It excludes Muslims, arguing that they cannot be considered persecuted minorities in Islamic republics. The act also does not cover Tamil refugees from Sri Lanka or Rohingya Muslims from Myanmar.
The implementation rules state that applicants must have resided in India for 12 months prior to applying or for six years out of the eight years preceding the 12-month period. Applicants must provide an eligibility certificate from a community institution and declare their intention to permanently reside in India. Certain northeastern regions are exempt from the CAA.
The government assures that the CAA does not change the status of Indian citizens. Opposition parties, however, criticize the timing of the notification, suggesting it aims to influence upcoming elections and expressing concerns over its potential use as a precursor to a nationwide National Register of Citizens (NRC). Critics argue that the CAA is discriminatory and divisive, while supporters claim it fulfills a constitutional promise to persecuted minorities from neighboring countries.

item.title: Explained: How Haiti turned into a failed state
item.description:
Haiti is experiencing a severe crisis as gangs have launched coordinated attacks, including sieges on the country's port and airport. The US military has evacuated embassy staff due to escalating violence, with gangs demanding the resignation of acting President Ariel Henry. Gang leader Jimmy "Barbecue" Chérizier has threatened civil war if Henry does not step down. The gangs have freed over 3,800 criminals from jails and caused 15,000 displaced persons to flee again. Haiti, one of the poorest nations in Latin America, has been without a legitimate government since the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse in 2021, and no new elections are scheduled. The country's weak regime is unable to control its territories, leaving it at the mercy of criminal gangs.
Historically, Haiti has struggled with violent gangs since the Duvalier dictatorship (1957-1986). The notorious "Tonton Macoutes" militia was disbanded in 1986, but its members continued to terrorize the population. After the 1990 democratic election of Jean-Bertrand Aristide, a military coup disrupted the transition. The dismantling of the Haitian army left a vacuum that enabled organized crime to flourish, with drug trafficking becoming a significant income source for Haiti's elites.
The 2010 earthquake exacerbated the situation, leading to the escape of thousands of inmates who joined criminal gangs. Currently, an estimated 200 gangs operate in Haiti, causing widespread insecurity and violence. The "G-9 and Family" federation, led by "Barbecue," is linked to the ruling Haitian Tèt Kale Party and controls key economic points through extortion.
The UN Security Council voted to send a Kenyan-led security force to Haiti, but the mission has been delayed. Haiti urgently needs an elected government to end the crisis, but the conditions for free and fair elections are not present, and the infrastructure is lacking. The status quo is unsustainable, and an election is long overdue.

item.title: Russia elections 2024: Key moments that define Vladimir Putin's presidency
item.description:
The article provides an overview of Russian President Vladimir Putin's tenure, highlighting five significant events that have shaped his rule:
1. **The Kursk Disaster (2000):** Early in Putin's presidency, the Kursk nuclear submarine sank, resulting in the death of all 118 crew members. Putin's delayed response and the handling of the situation drew criticism.
2. **Beslan School Attack (2004):** Islamic extremists took over a school in Beslan, leading to a siege that ended with over 330 deaths, including 186 children. The government's management of the crisis was widely condemned.
3. **Mass Protests (2011):** Putin's announcement to run for presidency again led to large-scale protests in Moscow, which were met with a severe crackdown and long jail terms for participants.
4. **Sochi Winter Games and Crimea Annexation (2014):** After hosting the Sochi Olympics, Putin annexed Crimea, leading to international sanctions and the start of a conflict in eastern Ukraine.
5. **Wagner Group Rebellion (2023):** Yevgeny Prigozhin, leader of the Wagner mercenary group, led a brief rebellion against the Russian military leadership. Following a failed mutiny, Prigozhin died in a plane crash, which sent a warning to Putin's opponents.
The article suggests Putin is poised to win a fifth term, extending his influence over Russia's future. It also touches on constitutional reforms that could allow him to stay in power until 2036. The summary omits unrelated content and focuses on the key points presented.

item.title: FirstUp: SBI to furnish electoral bond details & more… The big headlines
item.description:
Here's a summary of the key events covered in the article:
- The **State Bank of India (SBI)** is set to provide details on electoral bonds to the Election Commission as directed by the Supreme Court. - **Prime Minister Narendra Modi** will be in Ahmedabad to unveil railway projects worth Rs 8,500 crore and will also attend the 'Bharat Shakti' military exercise in Pokhran, showcasing India's defense capabilities. - The Supreme Court has ordered the SBI to disclose details of electoral bonds by today and expects the Election Commission to publish this information by March 15. - PM Modi's visit to Gujarat includes releasing the master plan for the Gandhi Ashram Memorial and Precinct Development project, and inaugurating a new Vande Bharat train service between Ahmedabad and Mumbai. - The 'Bharat Shakti' exercise in Pokhran will demonstrate various indigenously manufactured defense equipment, including LCA Tejas, ALH Mk-IV helicopters, and anti-ship missiles. - The Supreme Court will hear a plea from six disqualified Congress MLAs in Himachal Pradesh who were removed for cross-voting in the Rajya Sabha polls. - Rahul Gandhi's 'Bharat Jodo Nyay Yatra' will enter Maharashtra, aiming to spread the message of justice and connect with people across 15 states. - The IAEA Director General, Rafael Grossi, will visit Japan to inspect the situation at the Fukushima No. 1 nuclear power plant regarding the release of treated water into the ocean.
This summary excludes any unrelated content or advertisements that may have been present in the original article.

item.title: Mission Divyastra: What is the MIRV technology used by Agni-5 missile?
item.description:
India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced the successful maiden test flight of the Agni-5 missile using Multiple Independently-targetable Reentry Vehicle (MIRV) technology, marking a significant milestone for the country's defense capabilities. The Agni-5 is a nuclear-capable long-range missile developed by the Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO), and the use of MIRV technology allows it to deliver multiple warheads to different targets simultaneously. This achievement places India among a select group of nations with such advanced missile technology.
MIRV technology was first developed during the Cold War and allows a single missile to carry several nuclear warheads, each capable of striking separate targets. The United States was the first to deploy MIRVs in the 1970s, followed by other nations like the Soviet Union, the United Kingdom, France, China, and Russia. India's successful test signifies its entry into this exclusive club, with the Agni-5 missile capable of reaching targets up to 5,500 km away, including major Chinese cities.
The Agni-5 missile's advanced navigation systems and domestic avionics ensure high accuracy, and its development is seen as a response to regional security challenges, including Pakistan's test-firing of the MIRV-capable Ababeel missile. The Agni family of missiles has been a part of India's armed forces since the early 1990s, and the latest test underscores India's growing strategic defense capabilities.

item.title: No takers for wine? Why farmers in Australia, France are destroying vineyards
item.description:
The article discusses a global wine surplus, particularly affecting cheaper red wines, leading to the destruction of vineyards in major producing countries like Australia and France. Australia is significantly impacted, with growers destroying millions of grapevines due to overproduction that has plummeted grape prices and threatened their livelihoods. The decline in wine consumption, especially for cheaper reds, has resulted in excess stock, forcing some growers to sell at any price or destroy their vines.
The issue began in 2020, exacerbated by COVID-related cost increases and Chinese tariffs. The situation is not unique to Australia; similar problems are reported in California, Spain, and France. Governments are recognizing the challenges, with France allocating funds to destroy surplus wine to support producers.
Changing consumer habits towards less alcohol consumption and preference for higher-quality wines, along with increased production costs and geopolitical factors, have destabilized the wine industry's economic model. The industry's traditional nature makes quick adaptation difficult, and the future of wine, particularly for the next generation of drinkers, appears uncertain. The article concludes on a somber note, questioning the future of wine consumption and the industry as a whole.

item.title: Techies leave city, hospitals struggle: How Bengaluru’s water woes have upended lives
item.description: Bengaluru is facing a severe water crisis, leading to drastic measures and changes in the city's lifestyle. Hospitals are resorting to recycled water and borewells, while tech workers are leaving the city due to the unavailability of water. The crisis is attributed to the depletion of underground water and drought in the Cauvery basin, affecting all sectors from residential to industrial. The fire department and hotels are struggling with water scarcity, with some preemptively adopting water management systems. Social media users are urging for work-from-home mandates to reduce water demand, and the Bangalore Water Supply and Sewerage Board has banned the use of potable water for non-essential purposes, imposing penalties for violations. The Karnataka government is taking steps like controlling private water tankers and fixing prices, but experts suggest that the crisis is due to factors like unplanned urbanization and over-dependence on the Cauvery river. Solutions proposed include human-centric water governance, recycling, rainwater harvesting, and better water use planning.

item.title: Tensions run high at Jerusalem’s al-Aqsa mosque every Ramzan. Here’s why
item.description:
The article discusses the recent tensions at Jerusalem's al-Aqsa mosque during the first night of Ramzan, where Israeli security forces clashed with Muslim worshippers. The al-Aqsa mosque, a site of historical conflicts, is significant to both Muslims and Jews. For Muslims, it is the third holiest site, believed to be where Prophet Muhammad ascended to heaven. For Jews, it is the holiest site, where ancient Jewish temples once stood.
The current control of the mosque is under the Waqf, with Israel handling external security. This arrangement has led to past and recent clashes, including the 1969 arson attempt by an Australian Christian, the 1990 riots following an Orthodox Jewish group's actions, and the Second Intifada in 2000 after Ariel Sharon's visit.
Recent incidents include the 2014 closure after an attack on a right-wing rabbi, the 2017 anger over Israeli government meetings in tunnels under the mosque, and the 2021 clashes after Hamas fired rockets into Israel. In April last year, Israeli police clashed with worshippers, alleging rioting. Before this Ramzan, there were talks of entry restrictions for Palestinian worshippers, but Israel's Prime Minister dismissed the proposal, emphasizing the preservation of the holiday's sanctity. The article highlights the ongoing struggle over the site and its implications for Israeli-Palestinian relations.

item.title: No dissent, only despotism: How Russia has changed under Vladimir Putin
item.description:
The article discusses the evolution of political repression in Russia under Vladimir Putin's leadership. Initially, Russia was somewhat tolerant of dissent, but over the years, this has shifted to a severe suppression of opposition. The assassination of Boris Nemtsov and the death of Alexei Navalny in prison highlight this change. The Kremlin now targets not only political opponents but also rights groups, independent media, LGBTQ+ activists, and certain religious groups. The number of political prisoners has increased significantly, especially after the invasion of Ukraine.
Human rights advocate Oleg Orlov and exiled businessman Mikhail Khodorkovsky provide insights into the growing intolerance for dissent, which began subtly after Putin's rise to power in 2000 and has escalated to today's levels. The annexation of Crimea boosted Putin's popularity and led to further restrictions on NGOs and rights groups. The COVID-19 pandemic was used to ban protests, and Navalny's poisoning and subsequent arrest intensified crackdowns on opposition.
The invasion of Ukraine in 2022 brought new repressive laws, stifling anti-war sentiment and leading to a surge in arrests and trials. Prominent critics like Navalny and Vladimir Kara-Murza received lengthy prison sentences. The article also notes a trend of increasing trials in absentia and longer prison sentences. Independent news sites have been blocked, and the Kremlin has continued its crackdown on the LGBTQ+ community and religious groups like Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Despite the oppressive system, there are instances of defiance, such as the public mourning of Navalny, where police did not intervene. The article concludes with a statement on the Kremlin's efforts to maintain control through fear, but acknowledges that resistance still occurs.

item.title: After Netherlands, now Portugal: The surge of far-right across Europe
item.description:
In Portugal's general elections, the centre-right Democratic Alliance (AD) led by Luis Montenegro claimed victory with 79 seats but did not secure a majority in the 230-seat National Assembly. The Socialist Party, which has been in power for the last eight years, won 77 seats and conceded defeat. The far-right Chega party, led by Andre Ventura, made significant gains, winning 48 seats and 18% of the vote, up from 12 seats two years prior.
Montenegro has stated he will not form a government with Chega, despite their potential role as kingmakers in a conservative coalition. Chega's rise indicates a shift in Portugal's political landscape, ending the two-party system and aligning with the broader European trend of increasing far-right influence. This shift is evident as right-of-centre parties now hold at least 135 seats in Parliament. The election results reflect a changing dynamic in Portugal, which had been considered resistant to the far-right movement that is gaining momentum across Europe.

item.title: How much does it cost to host the Oscars, the biggest night in Hollywood?
item.description: The Oscars, Hollywood's most prestigious event, cost a staggering $56.9 million to host. The 96th Academy Awards saw Christopher Nolan's "Oppenheimer" win seven awards, including Best Picture and Best Actor for Cillian Murphy, while Emma Stone won Best Actress for "Poor Things." The event's expenses include the red carpet installation, production, security, and the host's fee, with Jimmy Kimmel earning over $150,000. Nominees receive lavish gift bags valued at over $180,000, featuring trips and luxury items. Celebrities also spend significantly on their attire for the event, with some outfits costing millions. Despite its high cost, the Oscars generate substantial revenue from advertising and boost Los Angeles' economy, while Oscar winners can expect increased future earnings. The Oscars remain the most significant awards in the film industry, reflecting both the glamour and the business of cinema.

item.title: What’s going on with Kate? The royal mess over a ‘manipulated’ picture
item.description: Kate Middleton's absence from the public eye following her abdominal surgery in January has sparked widespread speculation and concern. Kensington Palace attempted to quell the rumors by releasing a photograph of Kate with her children, which was later retracted by major news agencies due to suspicions of manipulation. The photo, claimed to have been taken by Prince William, was the first image of Kate post-surgery and was shared on social media with a Mother's Day message. However, inconsistencies in the photo, such as the alignment of Princess Charlotte's hand and the absence of Kate's wedding and engagement rings, led to its retraction. Agencies like AP, Reuters, and AFP have withdrawn the photo, citing editorial issues and manipulation. Kensington Palace has not commented on the controversy but had previously stated that Kate's surgery was successful and that she would be on a break from public duties until after Easter. Rumors about her health continue to circulate, ranging from serious conditions to cosmetic procedures, but the Palace has only promised significant updates on her recovery. The release of the altered photo has only intensified the scrutiny and speculation surrounding the Princess of Wales.

item.title: How gangs in Haiti have exploded and put the capital 'under siege'
item.description: The article discusses the escalating gang violence in Haiti, which has intensified since the assassination of President Jovenel Moise in 2021. Gangs, now powerful entities, are demanding the removal of Prime Minister Ariel Henry and have taken control of much of Port-au-Prince. The former police officer turned gang leader, Jimmy "Barbecue" Cherizier, is leading the charge against Henry, who is currently unable to return from Puerto Rico due to gang activity. Experts describe Haiti as a "narco-state," with gangs wielding more power than political and security institutions. They have been instrumentalized by the government since 2018 to suppress demands for political change. The gangs are not interested in legitimate power but seek to maintain control and profit from illegal activities. The international community, including the United Nations and the United States, supports a multinational mission to address the crisis, but there is criticism over the continued support of an unpopular political class and the effectiveness of foreign intervention. The article suggests that Haiti needs to strengthen its police and armed forces and allow Haitians to choose their own leaders for a long-term solution to the violence and political instability.

item.title: Hyderabad woman found dead in Australia: What we know so far
item.description: Chaithanya Swetha Madhagani, a 36-year-old woman from Hyderabad, was found deceased in a waste bin in Buckley, Australia. The body was located 84 km from her Point Cook residence. Swetha lived with her husband and son, and her husband is the primary suspect in her murder. He reportedly fled to India with their son after the incident. Local authorities and the Indian community in Melbourne have been deeply affected by her death. Swetha was known as an active community member and a friendly individual. Efforts are being made to transport her remains to Hyderabad, and although no arrests have been made, there is said to be no immediate threat to the community.

item.title: India, European bloc EFTA ink free trade pact: Who benefits and how?
item.description:
India has signed a comprehensive free trade agreement with the European Free Trade Association (EFTA), which includes Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, and Switzerland. This agreement, known as the Trade and Economic Partnership Agreement (TEPA), aims to open markets and phase out customs duties on many products, making Swiss goods more affordable for Indian consumers.
**Key Points of the TEPA:** - **Negotiation Period:** The deal was finalized after 16 years and 21 rounds of negotiations. - **Investment Commitments:** EFTA countries have committed to invest $100 billion in India, with an additional $50 billion for the first 10 years post-agreement implementation. - **Employment Generation:** The agreement is expected to create 1 million direct jobs in India. - **Benefits for India:** Indian consumers will benefit from lower prices on Swiss products due to reduced custom duties. Products like chocolates, watches, biscuits, seafood, fruits, coffee, oils, sweets, processed foods, and wine will become more affordable. - **Wine Tariffs:** Wines priced between $5-$15 will see a duty reduction from 150% to 100% in the first year, decreasing to 50% over 10 years. Wines over $15 will have an initial cut from 150% to 75%, reducing to 25% after 10 years. - **Other Products:** Watches, smartphones, bicycle parts, medical equipment, clocks, medicines, dyes, textiles, apparel, iron, and steel products will also be more affordable. - **Diamonds:** Tariffs on cut and polished diamonds will be halved from 5% to 2.5% over five years.
**Reactions to the Deal:** - **Prime Minister Narendra Modi:** Called it a watershed moment, emphasizing the deal's role in shared prosperity and a stronger partnership. - **Norway's Trade Minister:** Celebrated the deal for creating business opportunities and investments, and for bridging gaps between the nations.
**India's Other Trade Agreements:** India has similar agreements with Mauritius, the UAE, and Australia and is negotiating with the UK, Oman, and the EU. Talks with Canada are on hold due to political issues.
This agreement marks a significant step in India's trade relations, offering economic benefits and strengthening ties with the EFTA countries.

item.title: ‘Everyone Wins’: What’s in this year’s Oscars goodie bags?
item.description: The article discusses the "Everyone Wins" gift bags given to Oscar nominees, a tradition not officially affiliated with the Academy Awards. These bags, assembled by Distinctive Assets, contain luxury items, vacations, and various products. The 2024 bags include gifts for celebrity pets, three holiday packages, health and grooming products, kitchen appliances, and other high-end items. The value of the 2024 gift bag exceeds $170,000. The tradition has faced criticism for being tone-deaf, especially considering the economic struggles of many. The value of the bags has fluctuated over the years, with a peak value in 2016, followed by a lawsuit from the Academy of Motion Pictures against Distinctive Assets for trademark infringement. The focus of the 2024 bags is on supporting small businesses, minority-owned brands, and companies that give back. The article highlights the controversy surrounding the opulence of the gift bags amidst broader societal challenges.

item.title: FirstUp: SC to hear SBI plea on electoral bonds and more… The big news today
item.description:
Here's a summary of the key points from the article:
- The **Supreme Court of India** is set to hear a plea from the **State Bank of India (SBI)** seeking an extension to provide details on electoral bonds to the Election Commission. This follows a landmark verdict that deemed the electoral bonds scheme unconstitutional and ordered the disclosure of political donors. - **Prime Minister Narendra Modi** is scheduled to inaugurate the **Dwarka Expressway** in Gurugram, which is expected to ease travel between Delhi and Gurugram and spur development in new sectors. - The **BJP** in Karnataka is organizing a protest at Bengaluru's Freedom Park against the Congress-led state government over a severe water crisis in the city. - The **Congress party** is holding its second Election Committee meeting in Delhi to discuss candidates for the upcoming Lok Sabha elections. - **Sweden** has officially joined **NATO**, with a flag-raising ceremony planned at the alliance headquarters in Brussels to mark the accession, which is seen as a strategic move against Moscow.
The article also mentions the anniversary of the 2011 earthquake and tsunami in Japan, which had far-reaching effects and caused significant loss of life and damage.

item.title: Who are death doulas, those who assist at the end of people's lives?
item.description: Death doulas, also known as end-of-life doulas, are individuals who assist those with life-limiting or terminal illnesses, providing support that ranges from company and emotional care to help with funeral plans and care appointments. Their role is to improve the quality of life and death for the dying, as well as to offer support to their families and friends, often filling gaps in healthcare systems and informal care networks. They operate globally and are part of a growing movement that seeks to normalize conversations about death and dying, hosting workshops and death cafes to educate communities. The profession is unregulated, with training available internationally, and many doulas come from backgrounds in healthcare, social care, or education. Death doulas are not a substitute for specialized palliative care but serve to ensure a good death experience for individuals. The increasing demand for death doulas reflects a societal shift towards valuing end-of-life experiences and redefining what constitutes a good death. Erica Borgstrom, a professor of medical anthropology, highlights the importance of death doulas in supporting not just the dying but also those around them, bridging service gaps and advocating for better end-of-life care. The article emphasizes the non-medical, supportive role of death doulas and their contribution to the healthcare system and society's approach to death.

item.title: Why you should think twice before letting your dog lick your face
item.description: The article discusses the affectionate behavior of dogs licking their owners' faces, which can be heartwarming and beneficial for mental health. However, it also highlights the potential hygiene and health risks associated with this behavior. Dogs' mouths contain various microorganisms, and while most are low-risk, there are rare cases of serious illnesses transmitted to humans through dog saliva. High-risk individuals, such as the immunocompromised, should avoid face licks. The article also touches on the historical use of animal saliva for wound healing, but advises against it due to infection risks. Despite the potential hazards, the article suggests that for most people, occasional licks from a dog are safe with proper hygiene and healthcare. It concludes by recommending avoiding licks on the mouth for safety. The author, Jacqueline Boyd, is a Senior Lecturer in Animal Science at Nottingham Trent University. The article is republished from The Conversation under a Creative Commons license.

item.title: This Week in Explainers: Did self-help guru Jay Shetty lie about his past?
item.description:
This week's news roundup includes several significant global events:
1. **US Supreme Court Ruling**: The US Supreme Court unanimously overturned the Colorado Supreme Court's decision to disqualify former President Donald Trump from the ballot, citing the 14th Amendment. This ruling is pivotal for the upcoming November 9 election.
2. **Shehbaz Sharif's Return**: After political unrest in Pakistan, Shehbaz Sharif has been reappointed as Prime Minister. He faces numerous challenges, including economic crises and political opposition.
3. **Controversy Over Jay Shetty**: Allegations of dishonesty and plagiarism have surfaced against self-help guru Jay Shetty. Questions are being raised about the authenticity of his backstory and the operations of his coaching school.
4. **Ozempic and Weight Loss**: The diabetes drug Ozempic, known for aiding weight loss, is expensive and scarce, leading to the rise of 'budget Ozempic' alternatives on social media, despite medical warnings.
5. **France's Abortion Rights**: France has made history by constitutionally guaranteeing a woman's right to abortion, with a sweeping majority in Parliament supporting the amendment.
6. **Parrot Fever Outbreak**: Europe is facing a resurgence of Parrot fever, with cases reported in several countries and at least five fatalities. The article provides insights into the disease and its impact.
These stories highlight the week's major developments and their implications on international affairs.

item.title: How Elon Musk lost $40 billion of his fortune in three months this year
item.description:
Elon Musk, with a net worth of **$189 billion**, is now ranked third on the Bloomberg Billionaires Index, having lost his position as the world's richest man to Bernard Arnault. Musk's fortune has declined due to a **29% drop** in Tesla's share price this year. The decrease in Tesla's value is attributed to poor sales in China, a halt in production at its Berlin factory, and a Delaware court's rejection of a **$55 billion** compensation proposal. Additionally, Musk's acquisition of Twitter, now called X, has faced advertising challenges amidst controversies.
Other billionaires on the list include Mark Zuckerberg at fourth with **$182 billion**, Bill Gates at fifth with **$148 billion**, followed by Steve Ballmer, Warren Buffett, Larry Ellison, Larry Page, and Sergey Brin. Indian billionaires Mukesh Ambani and Gautam Adani are ranked 11th and 13th, with net worths of **$113 billion** and **$103 billion**, respectively.

item.title: Who is Faisal Khan, the YouTuber who duped Indians to work for Russian army?
item.description:
The article discusses the case of Faisal Khan, a YouTuber and manpower consultant who allegedly deceived Indian men with job offers in the Russian army. Khan, who runs the channel Baba Vlogs, expanded his recruitment to various countries, including Russia, from October 2022. He charged an initial fee and promised high salaries and safety for jobs that supposedly involved non-combatant roles. However, some recruits were later involved in the Russia-Ukraine war, leading to casualties among the Indians sent.
The Indian Ministry of External Affairs has intervened, seeking the early release of the duped individuals and dismantling a human trafficking network. The MEA has warned against such deceptive job offers and is working to repatriate the affected citizens. The article highlights the tragic outcomes for two Indian men, Mohammed Afsan and Hamil Mangukiya, who died in the conflict after being recruited as helpers for the Russian army. Faisal Khan defends his actions, claiming he is also a victim and that those he sent were aware of the risks. The Indian government continues to address the situation and assist the remaining individuals.

item.title: Why hundreds of school children in northern Nigeria are being abducted
item.description:
In a distressing development in Nigeria, over 280 grade school students were abducted from Kuriga in the country's northwest region. The incident occurred when gunmen on motorcycles stormed the school during assembly, taking students aged between eight and 15, along with a teacher. While 25 students have returned, the fate of the others remains uncertain. This event is part of a troubling trend of mass kidnappings in northern Nigeria, where armed gangs, known as bandits, have been terrorizing communities and schools, resulting in over 1,500 student abductions since 2014.
The bandits, often from the Fulani nomadic community, initially sought land and water resources but have since become organized criminal groups specializing in kidnappings for ransom and seizing farms and mines. The Nigerian military has been unable to disband these gangs, which now threaten the nation's food security by controlling key agricultural areas.
Kidnappings are primarily for ransom, a practice that has become increasingly profitable, with payments believed to be made by families and state governments. The resulting financial gains have allowed the gangs to amass significant arsenals. Despite some state governments attempting negotiations and amnesty deals, the federal government has opted for armed retaliation. However, the failure to effectively combat these kidnappers has led to a climate of impunity, further exacerbating the crisis.
The ongoing abductions have had a detrimental impact on education in northern Nigeria, with the region already suffering from low literacy rates and high numbers of children out of school. The fear of kidnappings is now discouraging parents from sending their children to school, posing a severe threat to basic education efforts in the area. President Bola Tinubu has expressed confidence in rescuing the victims, but the situation remains dire. The article concludes with a note on the pervasive climate of impunity and the challenges in dissuading gang members from the lucrative kidnapping trade.

item.title: Why Arunachal's Sela Tunnel is significant
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi inaugurated the Sela Tunnel in Arunachal Pradesh, which is expected to enhance all-weather connectivity and facilitate rapid military deployments to Tawang and Kameng. The tunnel, built at 13,000 feet by the Border Roads Organisation, consists of two tubes measuring 980 and 1,555 meters, with a link road of 8.6 kilometers. It incorporates advanced technologies like SCADA systems and jet fan ventilation, and can handle a significant volume of traffic with a top speed of 80 km/h. The project, completed with over 90 lakh man-hours, is part of India's strategic infrastructure development to strengthen border areas and improve socio-economic conditions in the Northeast. Additionally, PM Modi launched the UNNATI scheme and dedicated development projects worth Rs 55,600 crore across Northeastern states. He also unveiled the "Statue of Valour" in Jorhat and announced further development initiatives. The Sela Tunnel project underscores India's efforts to match China's border infrastructure and signifies a strategic move to ensure year-round access to Tawang.

item.title: What happens to coins thrown into Rome's Trevi Fountain?
item.description: The Trevi Fountain in Rome is not just a tourist attraction but also a source of charity. Coins thrown into the fountain by visitors, hoping for love, health, or a return to Rome, are collected and used to support the needy. In 2022, Caritas, a Catholic charity, gathered 1.4 million euros from the fountain, funding a food bank, soup kitchen, and welfare projects. The spectacle of extracting coins involves ACEA workers using brooms and hoses. The coins are dried, sorted, and counted at Caritas' office. The tradition, rooted in the belief that tossing a coin ensures a return to Rome, has been a part of the fountain's history since its completion in 1762. The fountain is also famous for its appearance in Federico Fellini's film "La Dolce Vita." While wading is prohibited, the coins continue to aid Rome's needy, with Caritas' Emporium providing food to those in need. The article concludes with anecdotes from tourists and locals who benefit from the fountain's charitable tradition.

item.title: This Week in Explainers: How dangerous is it to consume dry ice?
item.description:
Here's a summary of the key events from the article:
- **Health Scare in Gurugram**: Five individuals were hospitalized after consuming what they believed was a mouth freshener at a restaurant, which turned out to be dry ice, causing them to cough up blood. - **Tragic Incident in Jharkhand**: A Spanish tourist was subjected to a brutal assault and gang rape while traveling in India with her husband. - **Indians in the Russia-Ukraine War**: Several men from Punjab and Haryana were deceived into joining the Russian military to fight in Ukraine, leading to growing concerns for their safety. One man from Hyderabad lost his life in Russia under these circumstances. - **Life Insurance for Indian Workers in UAE**: The Indian consulate in Dubai introduced a life insurance scheme for blue-collar workers, promising compensation for their families in case of the worker's death. - **Water Crisis in Bengaluru**: The city is facing a severe water shortage, with residents struggling without regular water supply, leading to skyrocketing prices for water tankers. - **UPI Goes Global**: India's Unified Payments Interface (UPI) is now supported in several countries worldwide, potentially aiding developing nations.
These highlights cover the significant developments in India, from social issues to technological advancements.

item.title: Why France's Camembert cheese could soon disappear from kitchens
item.description:
The article discusses the potential extinction of France's beloved Camembert cheese due to a crisis in fungal diversity. The key points are:
- **Camembert cheese** is at risk because the **P. camemberti** fungi, essential for its unique characteristics, are struggling to reproduce. - Industrial manufacturing pressures are causing a **lack of microbial diversity**, leading to a limited supply of the fungus. - The **French National Center for Scientific Research (CNRS)** has highlighted that Camembert is on the verge of extinction, with blue cheeses also at risk. - A study by **Paris-Saclay University** indicates that the use of a limited number of fungal strains in cheese production is leading to genetic degeneration. - The **history of Camembert** dates back to the 18th century in Normandy, and it's considered a national treasure in France. - The **Appellation d’origine protégée (AOP)** designation has helped protect the name and production methods of Camembert. - There's a call for preserving microbial diversity to ensure the survival of species like Camembert, which are unable to adapt to environmental changes without it.
The article emphasizes the importance of biodiversity, even among microorganisms, for the sustainability of food products like Camembert cheese.

item.title: How agents lured Indians with fake jobs to go to Russia, fight Ukraine war
item.description:
The article reports on a major human trafficking operation where at least 180 Indians were duped into joining the Russian Army under false pretenses, mainly through student visas. The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) conducted raids across India and is investigating the roles of certain agents who facilitated this trafficking by offering lucrative job opportunities and admissions to dubious private universities in Russia. The victims' passports were seized upon arrival in Russia, and they were forced into combat roles and deployed to the front lines in the Russia-Ukraine War Zone.
The CBI's FIR lists 17 visa consultancy companies and their agents for criminal conspiracy, cheating, and human trafficking. The MEA has taken up the matter with the Russian government, urging the release of the Indian nationals and warning the public against such schemes. The CBI has seized over Rs 50 lakh, documents, and electronic records, and some suspects have been detained for questioning. The MEA spokesperson emphasized the danger of such offers and the commitment to the safe return of the nationals involved.

item.title: Half-bucket baths, school shuts: How Bengaluru’s water crisis is turning graver
item.description: Bengaluru is facing a severe water crisis, leading to the closure of educational institutions like Abheek Academy and Government Primary School in Hosakerehalli. The Bangalore Water Supply and Sewerage Board (BWSSB) has imposed restrictions on the use of potable water for non-essential activities. The Karnataka government has taken control of private water tankers and borewells to manage the situation. Residents have been advised to conserve water, and the BWSSB has set penalties for misuse. The district administration has regulated water tanker prices to alleviate the burden on citizens. The crisis, exacerbated by insufficient rainfall and depleted groundwater levels, has affected the city's 1.3 crore population, which requires 2,600-2,800 MLD of water daily, while the current shortage exceeds 1,500 MLD. Efforts are underway to address the issue, including mandatory registration for private water tankers.

item.title: Why US saw worst February for layoffs since 2009
item.description: The article discusses a significant increase in layoffs across various sectors, with a total of 84,638 job cuts announced in February, marking the highest level for the month since 2009. The technology sector leads in job cuts, although overall layoffs are down by 55% compared to the same period in 2023. Financial and transportation sectors have also seen substantial job losses. Major companies like Amazon, Google, and Microsoft have conducted significant layoffs, with various reasons cited including restructuring, store closures, and cost-cutting. However, there is an underlying trend of job cuts due to AI and automation, with companies possibly understating the impact of technological advancements on workforce reductions. The article suggests that the shift towards AI and automation is a key factor in the ongoing wave of layoffs, as businesses adapt to technological changes and seek to reduce costs following a hiring surge during the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite the current job cuts, it is noted that many of these companies are still larger than before the pandemic due to previous expansions. The article concludes with a broader look at layoffs in other sectors such as media, financial services, consumer and retail, health, and energy, highlighting the global nature of the trend.

item.title: Delhi gym owner murder: Why man stabbed son 15 times, prior to wedding
item.description: Gaurav Singhal, a 29-year-old gym owner in South Delhi, was tragically murdered at his residence on the night before his wedding.
